subject: Add KERs Selection Table
Add Storybook to PCF environment
Formatting QAC-R
Move ANOCOVERLA KER into DB

details.name: description
details.old_value:
*Tech Story*

As a QAC App Team Member,
I would like to follow the established process to move ANOCOVERLA KER from the KER Wrapper into the DB,
So that I can ensure the integrity of the KER queries.

*Steps to Complete*
* Mary is alerted via RocketChat that the ANOCOVERLA KER needs to be moved into the DB
* QAC dev team retrieves her changes (via git or Mary sending file updates)
* QAC dev team validates that the new DB KER works as expected (Behave tests still pass for that KER)
* QAC dev team removes the ANOCOVERLA KER from the KER wrapper
details.new_value:
*Tech Story*

As a QAC App Team Member,
I would like to follow the established process to move ANOCOVERLA KER from the KER Wrapper into the DB,
So that I can ensure the integrity of the KER queries.

*Steps to Complete*
* Mary is alerted via RocketChat that the ANOCOVERLA KER needs to be moved into the DB
--- ask Mary if she wants to generate upload statements from Ker Wrapper SQL
--- then take upload statements from Mary (or existing Ker Wrapper SQL) and transplant it into the database as a new .sql file.
* QAC dev team validates that the new DB KER works as expected (Behave tests still pass for that KER)
* QAC dev team removes the ANOCOVERLA KER from the KER wrapper
* new ANOCOVERLA data is obtained from Chris Welch
* new test dataset may contain different number of conditions per part than existing test dataset. Feature tests may need to be updated.

subject: Summary Widget: Load Time Widget
Update Endpoint Data Being Used
File Upload Input does not have focus when tabbing with a keyboard
Schema Check Summary: Total Exceptions Chart
Update Fortify to omit test files.
Remove the "Reset Button" on KERs Summary

journals.notes:
There is a branch 54036-remove-reset-button that exists with this code in gitlab.

We decided to remove a redundant piece of navigation in the application. When the KER results are complete, we previously had an additional action button that navigated the user to the "Start New QAC" screen. Since this link already exists in the main navigation, we felt that this button was redundant and could cause confusion. So, we're removing it.

AND GIVEN the application URL is "/"
AND GIVEN the active navigation tab is "Start QAC"
WHEN user clicks the file input / "Choose File" button and opens a file on their machine
THEN the name of the file is displayed in the file input label
AND THEN the "Run Schema Check" button is no longer disabled
AND THEN "Run Schema Check" is clicked to upload the file


GIVEN schema checks have been processed on a shape file
AND GIVEN schema check exceptions exist on the shape file

WHEN the screen initially displays
THEN the summary item is selected in the left nav of the results screen
AND THEN the application url is "/running-qac/schema-check-results"
AND THEN the summary of exceptions displays in the results content area
AND THEN the "Schema Check CSV" button exists in the summary header
AND THEN the "Run KERs" button exists in the summary header

WHEN user clicks on an exception from the left nav under the summary item
THEN the summary item is no longer selected in the left nav
AND THEN that exception is selected in the left nav
AND THEN the results for that exception shows in the results content area

WHEN user clicks back on the summary item in the left nav
THEN the exception is no longer selected
AND THEN the summary item is selected in the left nav
AND THEN the results area shows the summary

WHEN user clicks the "Schema Check CSV" button
THEN a .csv file containing the schema check exceptions is generated and downloads to the user's computer

*Note:* E2E tests are all saved in the cypress/e2e test folder. They do not run on Jenkins. See https://gitlab.gs.mil/sfd/qac_fullstaq/merge_requests/161 for additional context.

*Note:* The E2E tests cannot test whether the CSV is downloaded properly in the browser. This is currently covered by the integration Cypress tests, which mock that function.

subject: Update GDAL

details.name: description
details.old_value: The request for GDAL 2.4.3 was disapproved by the SWAP team, due to CVE 2019-17545: https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2019-17545. It looks like all versions up to 3.0.1 are affected. They recommended requesting 3.0.3
details.new_value:
The request for GDAL 2.4.3 was disapproved by the SWAP team, due to CVE 2019-17545: https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2019-17545. It looks like all versions up to 3.0.1 are affected. They recommended requesting 3.0.3


h2. Steps to Take
h3. 1. Update gdal in local dev env
- get new image for qacbackend/base
- install gdal >= 3.0.3 locally
- update codebase as needed for new version of library
- ensure app still works
h3. 2. Update gdal for PCF
- once #1 is finished, update environment.yml for gdal >= 3.0.3
- deploy via feature branch and make sure that the app still works


qacbackend/base on dockerhub: https://hub.docker.com/r/qacbackend/base/tags
lib gdal matching python gdal: https://stackoverflow.com/a/31618858/1113872
conda's environment.yml: https://docs.conda.io/projects/conda/en/latest/user-guide/tasks/manage-environments.html#create-env-file-manually

details.name: description
details.old_value:
Decide which queuing service to use
i.	Rabbit MQ (Celery)
     1.	A lot of setup, but work
     2.	Deploy to PCF
             a.1.	Setup separate queuing service	Can deploy locally through CF CLI (may need NGA credentials). 
     3.	Get docker running on local instance of the app
ii.	Redis Q [RQ]
     1.	Out of the box setup
     2.	Deploy to PCF
             a.	Can deploy locally through CF CLI (may need NGA credentials). 
     3.	Get docker running on local instance of the app
details.new_value:
Decide which queuing service to use
i.	Rabbit MQ (Celery)
     1.	A lot of setup, but work
     2.	Deploy to PCF
             a.1.	Setup separate queuing service	Can deploy locally through CF CLI (may need NGA credentials). 
     3.	Get docker running on local instance of the app
ii.	Redis Q [RQ]
     1.	Out of the box setup
     2.	Deploy to PCF
             a.	Can deploy locally through CF CLI (may need NGA credentials). 
     3.	Get docker running on local instance of the app

Notes:
 - Celery with RabbitMQ deployment to PCF was successful but with many unknowns requesting job status and result storage
 - RQ with Redis was not successful as the uri was not available to the app to route RQ to the redis storage and messaging
 - PCF requires an app for PCF to ping for Heart beats, running the task only is not sufficient

subject: Move ANOCOVERA KER into DB
Move ANY_SAMEID KER into DB
Correctly check auth token on initial load

details.name: description
details.old_value:
Currently the auth check returns 401 every time the page is refreshed. 

This is because the current check on the backend expects the token to come in as a query parameter while the frontend is sending a request with an authorization header.

Note:
Would prefer to keep the authorization token in the header and not be a query parameter.
details.new_value:
GIVEN I have valid token available
WHEN the token is passed in an XHR request to the server
THEN the server returns a 200 status

Acceptance Criteria: See checklist below

subject: Dynamically build KER list with an end point

details.name: description
details.old_value: Needs AC (Erik Olsen will update).
details.new_value:
Ensure that new KERs are displayed with the correct full name in the load table(table shown while running the KER checks).

AC:

GIVEN the KER checks are running
WHEN the user views the loading table
THEN all existing KERS title and full name are displayed in the loading table

GIVEN a new KER has been added to the database
WHEN a KER is run
THEN the new KERs title and full name appear on the loading table

GIVEN a KERS title or full name is changed in the database
WHEN a KER is run
THEN the changed KERs title and full name display correctly on the loading table

FOR PO APPROVAL:
-This is a tech debt card so the only AC to be verified is that the loading table displays as normal since the implementation	of how that table data is generated will have been changed


Additional information:

Currently the Ker list for the loading table is stored in the the /frontend/src/const/kersList.js. We would like to not have to manually update this list whenever a change is made to a KER title or full name. We would also like to not have to manually update this list whenever a KER is added. Based on the discussion in planning on 1/09 the implementation suggestion was to create an endpoint that fetches that necessary information from the database and returns it as a JSON object to be used in the LoadingTable component essentially replacing the hardcoded values in the kersList.js.

subject: [Tech Debt] Backend: Deprecate legacy KER code
display error message if user uploads polar data (outside UTM range)

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a user,
I would like to receive a specific error message if I upload polar data (outside UTM range),
so that I know why the QAC tool won't process my data.

Given I upload polar data (outside of UTM range),
When I run the prechecks,
Then I expect to see an error message telling me my data can't be processed because it's not within the UTM range.


*AC*
* specific error message is displayed to the user if they upload polar data (outside of UTM range)
details.new_value:

Note: This should look like the schema check errors that pop up on file upload (Try uploading the empty_directory.zip in QAC for an example)

so that I know why the QAC tool won't process my data.

Given I upload polar data (outside of UTM range),
When I run the prechecks,
Then I expect to see an error message telling me my data can't be processed because it's not within the UTM range.

Note: This should look like the schema check errors that pop up on file upload (Try uploading the empty_directory.zip in QAC for an example)

*Acceptance Criteria*
* specific error message is displayed to the user if they upload polar data (outside of UTM range - the outside range is 84 North and 80 South)
* We need the language for the error message that will display
* This is similar to prechecks (file check) which prevent the KERs from running.

subject: convert to UTM as part of data ingest

details.name: description
details.old_value:
*Tech Debt*

As a developer,
I would like to start work on the UTM-related KERs.

Given I upload a set of data in WGS84,
When the data is converted from shapefiles to PostGIS tables
Then we automatically specify an SRID as part of that conversion process


Steps to Complete
* include Python utm module in both requirements.txt and environment.yml
* use the utm module to determine utm zone of the uploaded data
    * MGCP data should be in 1x1 degree cells and should fall within one UTM zone
    * take the centerpoint of the 1x1 degree cell
    * polar data (outside of UTM range) will be handled in another story, if needed
* convert UTM zone to WKID/SRID
    * [not sure exactly how to do this yet]
* use SRID when doing conversion from shapefiles to PostGIS tables
    * see method insert_shapefile_into_database in shapefile_database_loader.py

*Other*
* throw an error is data outside of UTM range is provided


Other things (made be separate stories?)
* revisit PLLPROXFAIL KER (doesn't need to do inline conversion anymore)
* regarding shapefile export, will data need to be converted back to WGS84?

- create a lookup table mapping UTM zone to WKID/SRID
* see https://spatialreference.org/ref/epsg/32600
* see https://developers.arcgis.com/rest/services-reference/projected-coordinate-systems.htm
* UTM North Zones are 32601 - 32660
* UTM South Zones are 32701 - 32760

- include Python utm module in both requirements.txt and environment.yml
- use the utm module to determine utm zone of the uploaded data
* MGCP data should be in 1x1 degree cells and should fall within one UTM zone
* take the centerpoint of the 1x1 degree cell
* polar data (outside of UTM range) will be handled in another story, if needed

- when creating layers and features, convert source layer spatial reference to UTM
* see https://pcjericks.github.io/py-gdalogr-cookbook/projection.html for some examples
* see method insert_shapefile_into_database in shapefile_database_loader.py
* exact set of steps will need to be determined, but the link above should be pretty helpful
    

*Other*
- throw an error if data outside of UTM range is uploaded
* generic error is fine for now. will write another story to inform user of polar data uploaded

details.new_value:
*As a* QAC user with a data set 
*I want* to run an inspection on FEATOUTSIDE
*So that* I am notified of FEATOUTSIDE magnitude results

AC #1:
Given I have conditions
When I view the results
Then the KER shall display previous data (UID, Feature Name, FCODE) and Magnitude (meters to the 6th decimal)
AND the KER shall return previous data (UID, Feature Name, FCODE) and Magnitude (meters to the 6th decimal).

Notes:

This is a placeholder story until we determine what information is needed for magnitude from the MGCP community.

FEATOUTSIDE:
Part.......Good.......Bad.....Total
_________________________
...1.........25........27........52
_________________________
.Sum.........25........27........52


*From GAIT:* 

*Feature Coordinate Outside Whole-Degree Project Boundaries (FEATOUTSIDE)*

Vertex of an area Soil Surface Region feature extends below the whole degree minimum coordinate of the project.

This inspection can be applied to identify any vertices of point, area or line features (described by the primary participant specification) that lie outside the whole-degree boundaries of the project. This inspection can be applied to either 2D or 3D features; however, the outside test is always applied as a 2D test. The inspection first calculates the whole-degree latitude parallels and longitude meridians that are closest to the maximum and minimum longitude and latitude coordinates of features included in the project. Then it compares the latitude and longitude coordinates of each feature vertex (described by the primary participant specification) to identify those that are (a) greater than the maximum parallel or meridian or (b) less than the minimum parallel or meridian, and are more than tolerance distance from that parallel or meridian.

In this example, GAIT has identified a case where a single vertex of a Soil Surface Region area feature (circled in red) is 3.8 m below the minimum whole-degree latitude parallel in the project.

This inspection is intended for application to projects having outer boundaries that should align to whole degree lines of latitude and longitude, such as an MGCP one-degree cell. The inspection may return unwanted results when applied to projects that are not designed to align with whole-degree lines of latitude and longitude.

subject: Investigate Corrupt DB Issue

details.name: description
details.old_value:
*Tech Debt*

Recently, on both dev and acceptance PCF environments, the database has become corrupt, rendering the app unusable. The purpose of this card is to investigate why this is happening, and perhaps try out alternative databases.
Questions to consider or answer
# What is causing the database to become corrupted and how do we know when this happens?
# What alternatives to CrunchDB do we have, and are they more reliable? Tim has mentioned an RDS service tile that may be able to serve as an alternative to the CrunchyDB tile.
details.new_value:
*Tech Debt*

Recently, on both dev and acceptance PCF environments, the database has become corrupt, rendering the app unusable. The purpose of this card is to investigate why this is happening, and perhaps try out alternative databases.
Questions to consider or answer
# What is causing the database to become corrupted and how do we know when this happens?
# What alternatives to CrunchDB do we have, and are they more reliable? Tim has mentioned an RDS service tile that may be able to serve as an alternative to the CrunchyDB tile.

Notes:
 - Since the corrupt database occurs randomly, we were not able to investigate it thoroughly. The investigation should occur next time the database is corrupt, because the logs are available to troubleshoot from.
 - We do not recommend looking into alternative options until the database can be investigated.

subject: create automated load tests

journals.notes:
priority changed to medium.
we need an estimate for when we're going to be 'done' with this app.
part of that involves possibly re-architecting the application.
before we do this, we want to demonstrate that the app will have trouble supporting around 100 simultaneous users.

details.name: description
details.old_value:
TASK

As a QAC Team member,
I would like to have a set of automated load tests,
So that I can know how well the QAC app scales under heavy user load.

*Notes*
* Gatlin and Artillery are two options for writing the load test scripts. there may be others
* keep in mind the numbers from our previous story writing discussion regarding number of simultaneous users: maybe 100. it could be less than that.
details.new_value:
TASK

As a QAC Team member,
I would like to have a set of automated load tests,
So that I can know how well the QAC app scales under heavy user load.

*Notes*
* Gatlin and Artillery are two options for writing the load test scripts. there may be others
* keep in mind the numbers from our previous story writing discussion regarding number of simultaneous users: maybe 100. it could be less than that.

*Findings*
* Initial load tests were run with 50 and 100 users over 50 and 100 seconds with error rates of 11% and 66%, respectively, using only KER test data.
* Jeff mentioned in his RocketChat message on Dec 13th (qac_kers channel), that the largest production dataset he was able to run through QAC was 26 MB. A 40MB file errored out. For reference, the largest current test dataset is about 800 KB. And you can find production datasets of several hundred MB on redmine.
* My opinion (Eric S.) is that this data is enough to demonstrate that the QAC app still does not scale and that rearchitecting the app is necessary.

subject: Replace tabs/continue button header with reactive stepper

journals.notes: ac?

details.name: description
details.old_value: Acceptance Criteria:
details.new_value:
*Rough Draft*

*As a* QAC User
*I want* to see where I am in the QAC process
*So that* I know where I am in the process and can go back to any sections I've completed.

*Acceptance Criteria*
*GIVEN* I have completed the information required for a step

WHEN I view the indicator
THEN My previous step displays an icon indicating completion with a label,
AND THEN My current step displayed an icon indicating active,
AND THEN My future steps display an icon indicating inactive/incomplete, and a disabled label without a link.

AND WHEN I have uploaded a file and clicked the "Run Schema Checks" button
AND WHEN the schema checks are running
AND WHEN a loading screen is displayed
THEN I am able to see the stepper
AND see that I am on the Running Schema Checks step in the process

AND WHEN Schema Checks are complete
AND WHEN the Schema Check Results screen is displayed
THEN I am able to see the stepper
AND THEN the previous link is "Upload a file" which shows a completed state,
AND THEN the active step is "Schema Check Results".

AND WHEN I have clicked the "Run KERs" button
AND WHEN the KER Checks are running
AND WHEN a loading screen is displayed
THEN I am able to see the stepper
AND THEN the previous link is "Schema Check Results" showing a completed state.

AND WHEN KER Checks are complete
AND WHEN the KER Results screen is displayed
THEN I am able to see the stepper
AND THEN the previous link is "Schema Check Results" showing a completed state
AND THEN the active step is "KER Results"

Notes:
- There will be no links in the stepper
- The button will progress you through the stepper and set the new state/section
- Button text will change dependent on Section (see sketch file)
- Visited links will display a check, indicating you have already completed that section

Zeplin Link: https://app.zeplin.io/project/5dc2d833a1fc3c2347277907/dashboard?seid=5dd2d983e909b46237db46cf

subject: Remove zip files from temp directory
App not deploying to Dev
[Tech Debt] Stop concurrent builds in Jenkins

details.name: description
details.old_value:
Currently, if a build is ran in Jenkins, and another build on the same branch starts and gets to a stage using Docker, Jenkins will fail both builds as the Docker resources are shared. In other words, if a build 4 is in the @Build Backend@ stage and build 5 makes it to the @Build Backend@ stage, then Jenkins will fail one or both builds. 

The desired behavior is to not allow concurrent builds in order to stop the collision on shared resources.
details.new_value:
Currently, if a build is ran in Jenkins, and another build on the same branch starts and gets to a stage using Docker, Jenkins will fail both builds as the Docker resources are shared. In other words, if a build 4 is in the @Build Backend@ stage and build 5 makes it to the @Build Backend@ stage, then Jenkins will fail one or both builds. 

The desired behavior is to not allow concurrent builds in order to stop the collision on shared resources. 

Container names should use a standard starting to avoid special characters shifting to the front.

subject: [Tech Debt] Backend: PCF environment uses Miniconda and the development environment uses pip

details.name: description
details.old_value: by having an @environment.yml@ within the backend directory, the PCF environment uses miniconda for housing our app. If we remove the @environment.yml@ then PCF will use pip. Currently pip install fails within PCF.
details.new_value:
by having an @environment.yml@ within the backend directory, the PCF environment uses miniconda for housing our app. If we remove the @environment.yml@ then PCF will use pip. Currently pip install fails within PCF.


I found the following links to be helpful (ES).
* https://mothergeo-py.readthedocs.io/en/latest/development/how-to/gdal-ubuntu-pkg.html
* https://starkandwayne.com/blog/install-any-debian-package-with-your-cloud-foundry-app
* https://github.com/cloudfoundry/apt-buildpack/#using-a-ppa
* https://askubuntu.com/a/496529

details.name: description
details.old_value:

I found the following links to be helpful (ES).
* https://mothergeo-py.readthedocs.io/en/latest/development/how-to/gdal-ubuntu-pkg.html
* https://starkandwayne.com/blog/install-any-debian-package-with-your-cloud-foundry-app

I found the following links to be helpful (ES).
* https://mothergeo-py.readthedocs.io/en/latest/development/how-to/gdal-ubuntu-pkg.html
* https://starkandwayne.com/blog/install-any-debian-package-with-your-cloud-foundry-app
* https://github.com/cloudfoundry/apt-buildpack/#using-a-ppa
* https://askubuntu.com/a/496529
* https://ajurasz.github.io/2018-09-09-adding-deb-packages-to-cloud-foundry-instances/

details.name: description
details.old_value:
by having an @environment.yml@ within the backend directory, the PCF environment uses miniconda for housing our app. If we remove the @environment.yml@ then PCF will use pip. Currently pip install fails within PCF.


I found the following links to be helpful (ES).
* https://mothergeo-py.readthedocs.io/en/latest/development/how-to/gdal-ubuntu-pkg.html
* https://starkandwayne.com/blog/install-any-debian-package-with-your-cloud-foundry-app
* https://github.com/cloudfoundry/apt-buildpack/#using-a-ppa
* https://askubuntu.com/a/496529
* https://ajurasz.github.io/2018-09-09-adding-deb-packages-to-cloud-foundry-instances/
details.new_value:
by having an @environment.yml@ within the backend directory, the PCF environment uses miniconda for housing our app. If we remove the @environment.yml@ then PCF will use pip. Currently pip install fails within PCF.

*Findings:*
pip fails to install gdal on PCF because the PCF stack (cflinuxfs3) does not contain the Debian-level dependencies require for pip to be able to install gdal. You can use apt-buildback to install Debian packages, and while that is technically an experimental buildpack, it works fine. However, there's a catch, after doing the apt-get install via apt.yml, there are a few environment variables that need to exported to the location where those Debian packages are installed. I'm not sure if this is possible in PCF because at this stage in the deploy process (installing Debian and Python dependencies) everything is installed to a temporary folder that is named differently for each attempted deploy. This makes using pip for the gdal install impractical. I'm not going to say it's not possible because maybe I just haven't found the right way to do this. But given that the miniconda install works, it seems like it wasn't worth spending any more time on this approach.

I took an alternate approach of creating a Python script that compares the requirements.txt and environment.yml. This script will now be run near the beginning of the Jenkins pipeline and will fail at a specific step to inform the user of what is happening. This is slightly preferable to adding a new dependency to requirements.txt, but omitting it from environment.yml but not realizing that until the PCF deploy stage or later.

There is still at least one more approach we could try. We could use a Docker image as part of the PCF deploy. That Docker image would already have GDAL or the Debian-level deps already installed. My opinion on this approach is that this is also not worth the time at this point.

There are two branches for this story:
* 52499-compare-deps (keep)
* 52499-use-pip-in-pcf (for later if we get more information)

I found the following links to be helpful (ES).
* https://mothergeo-py.readthedocs.io/en/latest/development/how-to/gdal-ubuntu-pkg.html
* https://starkandwayne.com/blog/install-any-debian-package-with-your-cloud-foundry-app
* https://github.com/cloudfoundry/apt-buildpack/#using-a-ppa
* https://askubuntu.com/a/496529
* https://ajurasz.github.io/2018-09-09-adding-deb-packages-to-cloud-foundry-instances/

details.name: description

There are two branches for this story:
* 52499-compare-deps (keep)
* 52499-use-pip-in-pcf (for later if we get more information)

I found the following links to be helpful (ES).
* https://mothergeo-py.readthedocs.io/en/latest/development/how-to/gdal-ubuntu-pkg.html
* https://starkandwayne.com/blog/install-any-debian-package-with-your-cloud-foundry-app
* https://github.com/cloudfoundry/apt-buildpack/#using-a-ppa
* https://askubuntu.com/a/496529
* https://ajurasz.github.io/2018-09-09-adding-deb-packages-to-cloud-foundry-instances/
details.new_value:
by having an @environment.yml@ within the backend directory, the PCF environment uses miniconda for housing our app. If we remove the @environment.yml@ then PCF will use pip. Currently pip install fails within PCF.

*Findings:*
pip fails to install gdal on PCF because the PCF stack (cflinuxfs3) does not contain the Debian-level dependencies require for pip to be able to install gdal. You can use apt-buildback to install Debian packages, and while that is technically an experimental buildpack, it works fine. However, there's a catch, after doing the apt-get install via apt.yml, there are a few environment variables that need to exported to the location where those Debian packages are installed. I'm not sure if this is possible in PCF because at this stage in the deploy process (installing Debian and Python dependencies) everything is installed to a temporary folder that is named differently for each attempted deploy. This makes using pip for the gdal install impractical. I'm not going to say it's not possible because maybe I just haven't found the right way to do this. But given that the miniconda install works, it seems like it wasn't worth spending any more time on this approach.

I took an alternate approach of creating a Python script that compares the requirements.txt and environment.yml. This script will now be run near the beginning of the Jenkins pipeline and will fail at a specific step to inform the user of what is happening. This is slightly preferable to adding a new dependency to requirements.txt, but omitting it from environment.yml but not realizing that until the PCF deploy stage or later.

There is still at least one more approach we could try. We could use a Docker image as part of the PCF deploy. That Docker image would already have GDAL or the Debian-level deps already installed. My opinion on this approach is that this is also not worth the time at this point.

There are two branches for this story:
* 52499-compare-deps (keep)
* 52499-use-pip-in-pcf (for later if we get more information)

I found the following links to be helpful
* https://mothergeo-py.readthedocs.io/en/latest/development/how-to/gdal-ubuntu-pkg.html
* https://starkandwayne.com/blog/install-any-debian-package-with-your-cloud-foundry-app
* https://github.com/cloudfoundry/apt-buildpack/#using-a-ppa
* https://askubuntu.com/a/496529
* https://ajurasz.github.io/2018-09-09-adding-deb-packages-to-cloud-foundry-instances/

-* We can potentially setup a chron job if the approach above doesn't work.-
-* Investigate using file handler destructor to clean up data immediately after download.-

subject: SonarQube Findings - Fix these in development

details.name: description
details.old_value:
Based on feedback from Tim: 

Fix the following: 
- leading zeros within css files should not be used. example `.25` instead of `0.25`
- use `box-sizing: border-box;` where applicable
- quote font families in single quotes. example `'Arial'`
- cscc files should end in a new line (really all files should)
- simplify selectors where possible. Avoid `.checks .error-table .body .row .cell {` (5 items, sonar is looking for 3 max)
- Don't use `TODO` statements
- file name matches what it exports. `HttpHelper` instead of `HttpHelpers`
- class selectors should match `^[a-z][-a-z0-9]*$` `.usa-alert__text` should be `.usa-alert-text`
- Use single quotes for strings
- No empty functions or blocks of code
- Low cognitive complexity
- No commented out code
details.new_value:
Based on feedback from Tim: 

Fix the following: 
- leading zeros within css files should not be used. example `.25` instead of `0.25`
- use `box-sizing: border-box;` where applicable
- quote font families in single quotes. example `'Arial'`
- cscc files should end in a new line (really all files should)
- simplify selectors where possible. Avoid `.checks .error-table .body .row .cell {` (5 items, sonar is looking for 3 max)
- Don't use `TODO` statements
- file name matches what it exports. `HttpHelper` instead of `HttpHelpers`
- class selectors should match `^[a-z][-a-z0-9]*$` `.usa-alert__text` should be `.usa-alert-text`
- Use single quotes for strings
- No empty functions or blocks of code
- Low cognitive complexity
- No commented out code

*Note*
Several new stories were broken out from this one. Many of the items above will be handled in other stories.
* 53166 stylelint
* 52409 refactor precheck_engine
* 53146 refactor Results/index.js
* 53141 refactor ker_wrapper.py

subject: Windows Only - failure when checking zip files
prevent KER download when there's no relevant data to export

details.name: description
details.old_value:
At this point, we have two scenarios where an error happens on the backend and we need to know how to proceed.
1.	When a KER is loaded and there is no geometry populated on the KER (a KER we haven't worked on yet)
2.	There is no shapefile available for that KER. 

In either scenario, the user will load their file and cannot export a shapefile because the backend throws an error. 

Should we prevent completely the user from being able to select the "Export Shapefile" option? If we do let them, the user might get confused that they can select something, but then nothing happens. 

Currently, we have an error message on the backend. We are thinking we can display a message to the user, too. 
	This is what it currently states: Either no KER conditions have been found OR the KER conditions found cannot yet be exported to shapefile.
	Should this message be modified?
details.new_value:
As a quality assurance user running the KERs on the file I uploaded
I want to know if  there is an error with the KERs running
So that I know why the shapefile export drop down selection does not work

Given I am running KERs against the uploaded file
When I select the export shapefile drop down selection
Then the shapefile export option will not be avaialble
And I will see an error message display

Notes: 
At this point, we have two scenarios where an error happens on the backend and we need to know how to proceed.
1.	When a KER is loaded and there is no geometry populated on the KER (a KER we haven't worked on yet)
2.	There is no shapefile available for that KER. 

In either scenario, the user will load their file and cannot export a shapefile because the backend throws an error. 

Acceptance Criteria:
* We shouldn't let the customer export the shapefile because they cannot do anything when the error occurs. 
* The error message in the code should stay as is:  Either no KER conditions have been found OR the KER conditions found cannot yet be exported to shapefile.

details.new_value:
As a quality assurance user wanting to export shapefiles after running KER checks,
I want the UI to not allow downloading shapefiles of the conditions when there is no applicable data to export
So that I am not confused when I click export shapefile and nothing happens

Given I have already run KER checks against the uploaded file
When I select the export shapefile drop down selection
Then the shapefile export option will not be actionable
And I will see an error message display (*this may not be needed*: let UI/UX decide. disabled button/option may be sufficient)

Notes: 
At this point, we have two scenarios where an error happens on the backend and we need to know how to proceed.
1.	When the only KER conditions found do not have geometry populated on the KER (a KER for which we haven't done the corresponding results story). In this case, we have found conditions, but we can't export as shapefile because we're not ready to for those specific KERs.
2.	No KER conditions whatsoever have been found. In this case, there is nothing at all to export.

In either scenario, the user will run the KER checks but cannot export a shapefile because the backend throws an error. 

Acceptance Criteria:
* We shouldn't let the customer export the shapefile because they cannot do anything when the error occurs. The shapefile export option will not be actionable. 
* The error message in the code should stay as is:  Either no KER conditions have been found OR the KER conditions found cannot yet be exported to shapefile.
> * Clarification: error message only happens when the button is clicked and there's no data to export to shapefile. if button becomes "not actionable" in this scenario, user will not receive this error message because nothing happens when the button is clicked. perhaps UI/UX wants to add additional messaging in the UI in this case. that's their decision.

THEN a browser alert dialog appears "Sorry. There was no geometry data available to build your shape file. A CSV file is available for download."



==========================================

Context: 
At this point, we have two scenarios where an error happens on the backend and we need to know how to proceed.
1.	When the only KER conditions found do not have geometry populated on the KER (a KER for which we haven't done the corresponding results story). In this case, we have found conditions, but we can't export as shapefile because we're not ready to for those specific KERs.
2.	No KER conditions whatsoever have been found. In this case, there is nothing at all to export.

In either scenario, the user will run the KER checks but cannot export a shapefile because the backend throws an error. 

Additional context:
* We shouldn't let the customer export the shapefile because they cannot do anything when the error occurs. The shapefile export option will not be actionable. 
* The error message in the code should stay as is:  Either no KER conditions have been found OR the KER conditions found cannot yet be exported to shapefile.
> * Clarification: error message only happens when the button is clicked and there's no data to export to shapefile. if button becomes "not actionable" in this scenario, user will not receive this error message because nothing happens when the button is clicked. perhaps UI/UX wants to add additional messaging in the UI in this case. that's their decision.

Update the Jenkinsfile to use Blue-Green deployment within PCF. 

This may require that the frontend and backend be switched over at the same time.

* Add npm commands to run code coverage: `npm run coverage`
* Coverage files should not be checked into source control.

Display KERs which have passed under a tab on the KER Results Summary Page

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a user,
I would like to view all KERs, in the UI even those without exceptions (0)
So that I be assured that those KERs which did not return results are part of QAC and "ran"

Given I view KER results
When I click "show all KERs" (or something synonymous) 
Then all the KERs are shown in the left nav (including those with 0 results aka conditions aka exceptions)

Acceptance Criteria
All KERs shall return shapefile(s) with UUID, Feature Name, FCODE and [some type of] geom, and others. Please refer to the attached file for columns.

Notes from Conversation with Jeff
details.new_value:
As a user,
I would like to view all KERs, in the UI even those without exceptions (0)
So that I be assured that those KERs which did not return results are part of QAC and "ran"

Given I view KER results
When I click "show all KERs" (or something synonymous) 
Then all the KERs are shown in the left nav (including those with 0 results aka conditions aka exceptions)
And clicking on a KER with 0 results shows the title and description with no results table
And I can toggle back to original state with conditions greater than 0 ("Hide empty results", or something)

Acceptance Criteria
Button to toggle all vs. filtered ker results in the left nav
Left nav updates to show all vs. filtered
Results shows results table for kers with conditions like normal, and no table when empty

subject: Handle Individual KER failures

details.name: description
details.old_value:
*Acceptance Criteria:*
* Possibly return the KER check failure field (KER_Check_Failure) in the return object
* passed = false
* This helps the frontend know how to handle the failure

As a Quality Assurance user
I want to know what KERs failed during the KER processing
So that I know how to fix my file

Given a quality assurance user loads a KER file
When the KER file fails during the KER processing in the backend
Then communicate failure to the frontend
And note which KERs failed
And give a reason why the KER failed
details.new_value:
*Acceptance Criteria:*
* Possibly return the KER check failure field (KER_Check_Failure) in the return object
* This helps the frontend know how to handle the failure

As a Quality Assurance user
I want to know what KERs failed during the KER processing
So that I know how to fix my file

Given an individual KER has failed to run 
When the other KERs continue to run
Then the status of the fail KERs is displayed to the user

As a Quality Assurance user
I want to know what KERs failed while other KERs processed
So I know who to contact about the error

Given an individual KER has failed to run 
When the other KERs continue to run
Then the status of the fail KERs is displayed to the user 
AND Then a link will be provided for support

*NOTE: Design Needed*

details.new_value:
As a Quality Assurance user
I want to know what KERs failed while other KERs processed
So I know who to contact about the error

GIVEN KERs are being processed
WHEN an individual KER has failed to run
THEN non-failing KERs continue to run
AND THEN the status of all KERS that failed to run are displayed in an alert dialog in the KERs summary
AND THEN the alert dialog displays links to upload a new file and contact support

Acceptance Criteria: See checklist below

AND THEN the alert dialog displays links to upload a new file and contact support

subject: SPIKE: Develop Components in Isolation with Storybook

details.name: description
details.old_value:
When developing components, we need a way to manually approve the components without first integrating them into our application.

Questions we need answered:
* Can our PO easily test a component without it being used in the app?
* Can our component stories move across the board without the component being used within the app?

Notes:
Storybook docs: https://storybook.js.org/docs/basics/introduction/

subject: [TECH DEBT] Refactor KER exception object

journals.notes:
To the poor soul who picks this up,

There is a branch already created called `52157-ker-exception-refactor`
Look over the changes. I have essentially taken out the combine method in favor of just having a list of exceptions.
A few caveats:
1) The new structure is really only working as expected for the kers that already get additional information(UID and GEOM). All the other kers go though the "legacy" path.
2) The tests that handle the old data structure were not updated (Sorry! Sorry! Sorry! It was getting pretty late, but some tests should go away which brings me to: 
3) I have commented out any methods that I think could go away. (combine method should also be cleaned up, or not exist?)

Other information Brain dump:
1) We have a few cards (V_DUPS and ANY_SAME_ID) blocked while we wait for Mary to review. NBD, but we do need those cards to go through before this refactor takes place. (right now on dev, this refactor makes no sense because the code we are refactoring was introduced by #51434 V_dups)
2) V_Dups should be merged first? then ANY_SAME_ID, because "technically" ANY_SAME_ID was branched off of V_DUPS. 
Now is where it gets complicated...
3) MULTIPARTP results, was branched from ANY_SAME_ID to get the updated code changes. The refactor branch was branched off of #51437 which is the MULTIPARTP branch. I think the work can be referenced, but we may want to create a patch or something and apply it to dev after V_DUPS and ANY_SAME_ID have been merged.

Hope all this makes sense. If not, definitely do not hesitate to message me on slack (sorry rocket chat folks, I don't have that on my phone)

- Kevin

subject: SPIKE: identify portions of the code to optimize

details.name: description
details.old_value:
*Tech Story*

There are a lot of nested for-loops in the Python code.
It is believed that some of this code could be optimized in order to speed up processing time of the KERs, possibly eliminating timeouts visible to the user in the frontend.

The point of this spike is to identify parts of the codebase that can be optimized or refactored. However, we don't want to do this blindly, so we should probably add some simple benchmarking as part of this spike to demonstrate that our changes had the desired effect.

details.new_value:
*Tech Story*

There are a lot of nested for-loops in the Python code.
It is believed that some of this code could be optimized in order to speed up processing time of the KERs, possibly eliminating timeouts visible to the user in the frontend.

The point of this spike is to identify parts of the codebase that can be optimized or refactored. However, we don't want to do this blindly, so we should probably add some simple benchmarking as part of this spike to demonstrate that our changes had the desired effect.

Notes:
* Document/visualize where time is spent so we can understand what the next steps will be.

Results:
* After adding some basic profiling, we found that the KER ANY_SAMEID takes about 30 times longer than the rest of the KERs.
* The reason for this is because with the current setup for DB KERs, over 70,000 queries are being run for ANY_SAMEID.
* Additionally, we did a quick proof of concept by manually generating a union across all tables and then doing the KER check SQL on the resultant dataset. This dramatically decreases the amount of time for that KER to run since we're running approximately 70,000 fewer queries.

* Results: *
* After adding some basic profiling, we found that the KER ANY_SAMEID takes about 30 times longer than the rest of the KERs. (30s vs 1.5s or less)
* The reason for this is because with the current setup for DB KERs, over 70,000 queries are being run for ANY_SAMEID.
* Additionally, we did a quick proof of concept by manually generating a union across all tables and then doing the KER check SQL on the resultant dataset. This dramatically decreases the amount of time for that KER to run since we're running approximately 70,000 fewer queries. (30s vs < 100ms !!)

As a user,

So that I can make an informed decision about the quality of my geospatial data.

Given I run a KER check,

details.new_value:
As a user,
I would like to download a shapefile with real data,
So that I can make an informed decision about the quality of my geospatial data.

Given I run a KER check,
When I click "Download Shapefile",
Then I download a shapefile with real data corresponding to the results of the KER check I just ran.

Acceptance Criteria
All KERs shall return shapefile(s) with UUID, Feature Name, FCODE and [some type of] geom, and others. Please refer to the attached file for columns.

*Notes from Conversation with Jeff*
* it is preferred to have all found KER conditions in the same shapefiles. We do not want separate shapefiles per type of KER.
* name of the output file can be as follows: <name_of_input_zipfile>_results.zip
* a single shapefile per geometry type is OK. so we'll have one shapefile for all points, one for polygons, etc. this is due to a restriction of the shapefile format itself: one type of geometry per shapefile.
* if one input shapefile contains multiple KER conditions, then the output shapefile downloaded should have one entry per KER condition

* shapefiles are generated in the /tmp directory. we'll need a separate story to address cleanup of these files and other temp files

Then I would like to see the following fields in the results table for all KERs:

Condition Number, FCODE, table name?, fid?, uid?, feature name

Given I have run a KER check for a specific test dataset,
When I am viewing the KER results,
Then I would like to _also_ see the following additional fields:
- For MULTIPART_[ALP]: also display Magnitude (number of parts)
- For LBNDUSHT: also display Magnitude (meters to the 6th decimal)


*Questions that need to be answered*
# do we want condition number displayed in the prechecks as well?
# what do we do for multiple conditions per feature?
# should numbering increase across all KER checks, or start at 1 for each KER check?
# same as previous question, but for prechecks, IF we want condition number for the prechecks
# table name and fids are older fields. should we remove these?
# uid is a new field, is this helpful to the user? if not, should we remove this?
# do we want these columns in a certain order?

details.new_value:
As a user,
I would like to see specific fields when viewing KER results,
So that I can detect KER conditions and address them appropriately.

Given I have run a KER check on a test dataset,
When I am viewing the KER results,
Then I would like to see the following fields in the results table for all KERs:

Condition Number, FCODE, table name?, fid?, uid?, feature name

Given I have run a KER check for a specific test dataset,
When I am viewing the KER results,
Then I would like to _also_ see the following additional fields:
- For MULTIPART_[ALP]: also display Magnitude (number of parts)
- For LBNDUSHT: also display Magnitude (meters to the 6th decimal)


*Questions that need to be answered*
# do we want condition number displayed in the prechecks as well?
A: Yes

# what do we do for multiple conditions per feature?
A: Report each separately if it is from a different KER; we'll need more discussion if it is the same feature and KER.

# should numbering increase across all KER checks, or start at 1 for each KER check?
A: Begin at #1 for each KER

# same as previous question, but for prechecks, IF we want condition number for the prechecks
A: Begin at #1 for each Schema Check

# table name and fids are older fields. should we remove these?
A: Yes

# do we want these columns in a certain order?
A: Condition/Exception number, Feature name, FCODE, Magnitude (where necessary)

# uid is a new field, is this helpful to the user? if not, should we remove this?
A; Yes, for display results onscreen

subject: Move OBJECTWITHOUT KER into DB

details.name: description
details.old_value:
*Tech Story*

As a DBA,
I would like to follow the established process to move OBJECTWITHOUT KER from the KER Wrapper into the DB,
So that I can ensure the integrity of the KER queries.

*Steps to Complete*
* [DONE] Mary is alerted via RocketChat that the OBJECTWITHOUT KER needs to be moved into the DB
* Mary does the work of moving OBJECTWITHOUT KER into the DB and pushes hePO r changes (on a branch)
* QAC dev team fetches to get her changes
* QAC dev team validates that the new DB KER works as expected (Behave tests still pass for that KER)
* QAC dev team removes the OBJECTWITHOUT KER from the KER wrapper

*Tech Story*

As a QAC App Team Member,
I would like to follow the established process to move OBJECTWITHOUT KER from the KER Wrapper into the DB,
So that I can ensure the integrity of the KER queries.

*Steps to Complete*
* Mary is alerted via RocketChat that the OBJECTWITHOUT KER needs to be moved into the DB
* Mary does the work of moving OBJECTWITHOUT KER into the DB and pushes her changes (on a branch). --> this time Mary sent me the updated LOAD_KERS.sql, which is saved as an attachment to this story.
* QAC dev team fetches to get her changes --> in this case, just manually update the .sql file
* QAC dev team validates that the new DB KER works as expected (Behave tests still pass for that KER)
* QAC dev team removes the OBJECTWITHOUT KER from the KER wrapper

*Acceptance Criteria:*
* This KER shall display Magnitude (meters to the 6th decimal), FID, Feature Name (with FCODE).
* This KER shall return shapefile(s) with FID, Feature Name, FCODE and location.

*+Notes:+*
*Vertex of line Cart Track feature lies 0.11 m inside Sample project maximum latitude boundary*
This inspection can be applied to any line feature (as specified by the primary participant) to detect those with end nodes (either first or last node) that are inside the minimum and maximum, whole-degree lines of longitude and latitude that define the project and are distant from that latitude or longitude by an amount that lies within the open interval defined by the primary and secondary tolerances. That is, the end node is further away from the meridian or parallel then the distance specified as the primary tolerance and the end node to closer to the meridian or parallel than the distance specified by the secondary tolerance. This inspection is intended to compliment the inspection Feature Coordinate Outside Project Whole-Degree Boundaries (Containment group) by allowing a capability to identify line feature end nodes with coordinates that are very close to MGCP one-degree project boundaries, but do not exceed those boundaries. Above, GAIT has detected a vertex of a line Cart Track feature very close to (0.11 m) the northern latitude boundary in the Sample project. The same feature also includes another vertex that is on the latitude boundary and the inspection does not report this second vertex as a condition as its distance to the latitude boundary is less than the inspections primary tolerance.
LBNDUSHT.JPG

subject: [SPIKE] Dependencies with the KER Master statement

details.name: description
details.old_value:
AC:

How do we know that if a KER master statement changes that it will affect other KERs?

What If a KER is uploaded in the database without the Master Statement first?
details.new_value:
AC:

*How do we know that if a KER master statement changes that it will affect other KERs?*
*Answer*: Mary handles this. When she reviews the SQL and changes and validates that it is correct, and then makes a note for future statements.

*What If a KER is uploaded in the database without the Master Statement first?* 
*Answer*: this is a known issue. It will cause problems if we do that, which is why there is an order to the load.sql and to the KERs that are chosen.

subject: SPIKE: Update frontend (only) for KERs running as background jobs

details.name: description
details.old_value:
Once the KERs are running as a background job, we need to update the frontend to handle that.

*Questions to Answer*
1. How exactly do we implement long-polling on the frontend?

2. How to display status to the user?
    - Simple text Pending or finished
    - Once finished, display results or link to results
    - Duck may be spinning for a long time. thats ok

3. Can we demonstrate that long polling is  actually working?
    - Reduce resources of infrastructure
    - Send huge dataset through QAC (ask Jeff)

4. Does solution work with standalone version of the app?

*Notes*
This story is dependent on backend spike to process KERs as background jobs

See following article as a reference / possible approach for this work.
[[https://blog.miguelgrinberg.com/post/the-flask-mega-tutorial-part-xxii-background-jobs]]


*Assumptions / Things handled later*
- Updated frontend design for progress/status

subject: SPIKE: Convert KER processing to background job

details.name: description
details.old_value:
KER processing can take a long time to run. We need to update the backend to run this processing as a background job so that the browser doesn't wait for a long-running request that will timeout.

*Questions to Answer*
- Which task processing mechanism will me used?
    - Probably RabbitMQ due to integration w/ PCF
- How will tasks be persisted?
    - Likely by using existing PostgreSQL DB
- Does this solution work with standalone instance of app?

*Notes*
See following article as a reference / possible approach for this work.
[[https://blog.miguelgrinberg.com/post/the-flask-mega-tutorial-part-xxii-background-jobs]]


*Assumptions / Things handled later*
- No notion of users right now, anyone can access anyone's results
- Dont limit the number of background jobs running at once
- No way to cancel a job once its started
- When/how to delete job statuses

details.name: description
details.old_value:
KER processing can take a long time to run. We need to update the backend to run this processing as a background job so that the browser doesn't wait for a long-running request that will timeout.

*Questions to Answer*
1. Which task processing mechanism will me used?
- Probably RabbitMQ due to integration w/ PCF

2. How will tasks be persisted?
- Likely by using existing PostgreSQL DB

3. Does this solution work with standalone instance of app?

*Notes*
See following article as a reference / possible approach for this work.
[[https://blog.miguelgrinberg.com/post/the-flask-mega-tutorial-part-xxii-background-jobs]]


*Assumptions / Things handled later*
- No notion of users right now, anyone can access anyone's results
- Dont limit the number of background jobs running at once
- No way to cancel a job once its started
- When/how to delete job statuses

KER processing can take a long time to run. We need to update the backend to run this processing as a background job so that the browser doesn't wait for a long-running request that will timeout.

*Questions to Answer*

* See attached picture for guidance on this story.
* Also, in light of a recent discussion, it might make more sense to combine this spike with the related frontend spike 51587

*Assumptions / Things handled later*
- No notion of users right now, anyone can access anyone's results
- Dont limit the number of background jobs running at once
- No way to cancel a job once its started
- When/how to delete job statuses

journals.notes:
1. Which task processing mechanism will me used?
 -  The 2 popular background task queues for python are Celery (http://www.celeryproject.org/) and RQ (https://python-rq.org/).
    Both options require a separate server to run workers which are listening for messages to run tasks
    Celery:
        Celery allows high customization with broker integration and backend storage options. 
        Brokers include RabbitMQ, Redis, AmazonSQS.  
        Backend results can be stored using SQLAlchemy, Redis, RPC, or you can define a custom storage.
    RQ:
        RQ is a Redis specific job queue.
        Only allows storage and brokers using Redis

2. How will tasks be persisted?
    - Answered above with storage options.

3. Does this solution work with standalone instance of app?
    - A standalone instance would require another server running the queue worker through docker orchestration.

A spike branch was created with the name 51586-spike-background-processes using Celery queues with RabbitMQ and RPC.  
It allows sql queries to be tasked and returns job ids to the frontend.  
This was just experimental to see if Celery could be integrated with the current application.
The ./run_dev.sh start script should allow the Celery server and normal dev environment to spin up.

details.new_value:
*As a* QAC User
*I want* to see where I am in the QAC process
*So that* I know where I am in the process and can go back to any sections I've completed.

*Acceptance Criteria*
- Links for incomplete sections will be disabled.
- The button will progress you through the stepper and set the new state/section
- Button text will change dependent on Section (see sketch file)
- Clicking on a link will change the state of the app to the corresponding link, and set the link to active
- Visited links will display a check, indicating you have already completed that section
- Hovering over a completed state will remove the underline on the text

details.new_value:
*As a* QAC User
*I want* to see where I am in the QAC process
*So that* I know where I am in the process and can go back to any sections I've completed.

*Acceptance Criteria*
GIVEN I have completed the information required for a step

WHEN I view the indicator
THEN My previous step displays a "completed checkmark," a label, and link to display it
AND THEN My current step displayed a "current checkmark" and a label
AND THEN My future steps display a "disabled checkmark" and a label

AND WHEN I click the step link
THEN I am navigated to the completed step

AND WHEN the previous step is "Run Schema Checks"
THEN I am able to upload a new file

AND WHEN the previous step is "Run KERs"
THEN the KERs re-run

AND WHEN the previous step is "Schema Check Results" or KERs Results"
THEN I can view the associated results

AND WHEN I click an active main CTA
THEN the next step is run

Notes:
- Links for incomplete sections will be disabled.
- The button will progress you through the stepper and set the new state/section
- Button text will change dependent on Section (see sketch file)
- Clicking on a link will change the state of the app to the corresponding link, and set the link to active
- Visited links will display a check, indicating you have already completed that section
- Hovering over a completed state will remove the underline on the text

details.name: description
details.old_value:
AC:

This KER shall display FID, Feature Name, and FCODE.
This KER shall return shapefile(s) with FID, Feature Name, FCODE and location.
details.new_value:
*Acceptance Criteria:*
* This KER shall display FID, Feature Name, and FCODE.
* This KER shall return shapefile(s) with FID, Feature Name, FCODE and location.

*+Notes:+*
*Area Power Substation feature without a line Power Line feature (nearest Power Line (shown in red at top right) is no closer than 8 m)*
This inspection can be applied to identify instances of area features (described by the primary participant specification) that do not include any point or part of a line or area feature (described by the secondary participant specification) inside their perimeter. This inspection can be applied to either 2D or 3D features; however, the inside test is always applied as a 2D test. GAIT will consider a line or area feature vertex that lies exactly on the perimeter of a qualifying area to be inside that area feature. Also, a line feature only partially inside the area feature will satisfy the requirement. In the above example, GAIT has identified a case where an area Power Substation feature does not include any part of a line Power Line feature. The condition is described in the condition's detailed information window and highlighted in red on the main screen. This inspection can be configured to ignore conditions on the extreme boundaries of a project. See the earlier section of this document, Conditions on the Project Outer Edges for more information on the operation and use of this filtering capability.
OBJECTWITHOUT.JPG

details.name: description
details.new_value:
AC:

This KER shall display FIDs, Feature Name of the features with conditions (with FCODEs), e.g. Road and River (LAP030 and LBH140).
This KER shall return shapefile(s) with FID, Feature Name, FCODE and location.

details.name: description
details.old_value:
AC:

This KER shall display FIDs, Feature Name of the features with conditions (with FCODEs), e.g. Road and River (LAP030 and LBH140).
This KER shall return shapefile(s) with FID, Feature Name, FCODE and location.
details.new_value:
*Acceptance Criteria:*
* This KER shall display FIDs, Feature Name of the features with conditions (with FCODEs), e.g. Road and River (LAP030 and LBH140).
* This KER shall return shapefile(s) with FID, Feature Name, FCODE and location.

*+Notes:+*
*Area River feature that includes two parts*
This inspection can be applied to any area feature to identify those that include more than a specified number of parts. The number of parts that comprise an individual feature is defined in the input (source) data from which GAIT constructs its project. (Note that inner rings and outer rings are not different parts unless they are so designated in the input data.) When input data has more than a single part, GAIT preserves that information so that the multi-part features can be identified. The above example illustrates GAIT identification of a single area River feature that includes two parts. Each of the parts will be listed as an individual condition in the list of specific conditions and each part will contribute to the number of identified conditions. That is, this single River feature would result in two multi-part area feature conditions, both of which would be tallied in the total number of conditions and both of which will have the same magnitude. As each part is an individual condition listed in the specific conditions list, each part can be described individually, as shown above. The condition magnitude is 2 as the River feature has two parts. One of the two parts is described in the conditions detailed information window. The several parts of the same feature are always listed consecutively in the list of conditions. Note that both parts are highlighted on the main screen. The feature part corresponding to the illustrated specific condition is drawn using a bold red line to distinguish it from the other parts of the same feature. Parts that are not selected will be drawn in red, but not bold red.
FEATNOTCUT.JPG

*+Notes:+*
*Area River feature that includes two parts*
This inspection can be applied to any area feature to identify those that include more than a specified number of parts. The number of parts that comprise an individual feature is defined in the input (source) data from which GAIT constructs its project. (Note that inner rings and outer rings are not different parts unless they are so designated in the input data.) When input data has more than a single part, GAIT preserves that information so that the multi-part features can be identified. The above example illustrates GAIT identification of a single area River feature that includes two parts. Each of the parts will be listed as an individual condition in the list of specific conditions and each part will contribute to the number of identified conditions. That is, this single River feature would result in two multi-part area feature conditions, both of which would be tallied in the total number of conditions and both of which will have the same magnitude. As each part is an individual condition listed in the specific conditions list, each part can be described individually, as shown above. The condition magnitude is 2 as the River feature has two parts. One of the two parts is described in the conditions detailed information window. The several parts of the same feature are always listed consecutively in the list of conditions. Note that both parts are highlighted on the main screen. The feature part corresponding to the illustrated specific condition is drawn using a bold red line to distinguish it from the other parts of the same feature. Parts that are not selected will be drawn in red, but not bold red.

details.new_value:
*Acceptance Criteria:*
* This KER shall display UID, Feature Name, and FCODE.
* This KER shall return UUIDs, Feature Names, FCODEs, and location.

*+Notes:+*
This KER can identify single line features (defined by the primary participant specification) that have not been cut into multiple features at the point(s) where they coincide with the end node of a second line feature (defined by the secondary participant specification). The two line features must have at least one segment in common and the end point of the second line feature (where the first feature should have been cut) must not be connected to a like feature (i.e., another line feature meeting the secondary participant specification) for the inspection to apply. Also, there is a tolerance associated with the KER that is used in both the overlap and end node coincidence determinations. If the two features have segments that are nearly overlapping (within the tolerance distance) and the two features have end points that are more than the tolerance distance apart, a condition will be generated.

The two line features must have at least one segment in common and the end point of the second line feature (where the first feature should have been cut) must not be connected to a like feature (i.e., another line feature meeting the secondary participant specification) for the inspection to apply. Also, there is a tolerance associated with the KER that is used in both the overlap and end node coincidence determinations. If the two features have segments that are nearly overlapping (within the tolerance distance) and the two features have end points that are more than the tolerance distance apart, a condition will be generated.

* Question *
Currently, the behavior of the application is to identify and return the inner feature in this comparison (the bridge or tunnel). Is this desirable, or do we want to instead display the outer feature (road, railway, etc.) to the user? The language of the KER description seems to suggest that we should be identifying the outer feature because it is the feature that was not cut properly.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* This KER shall display FIDs, Feature Name of the features with conditions (with FCODEs), e.g. Road and River (LAP030 and LBH140).
* This KER shall return shapefile(s) with FID, Feature Name, FCODE and location (geom)

*Questions:*
* What does it mean when two different features with the same identifier will fail? 

*Notes:*
* The Gait manual should help with each 'results' story.

journals.notes:
*Any Two Features With The Same Identifier (ANY_SAMEID)* 
 
*Line Cart Track and Road features with the same unique identifier*
This inspection can be applied to any pair of point, line or area features to identify those cases where the two features (described by the primary and secondary participant specifications) have exactly the same unique identifier. Features that do not have an assigned identifier and features that have been assigned an identifier attribute, but the value has been left blank will not be considered by this inspection. This inspection will report any two features, regardless of geometry or attribution, that have exactly the same (non-blank) value as their unique identifier (either UFI, GFID, FLDBID or UID). This inspection has been designed to work in concert with the Complete Duplicates inspection. Both of these inspections are frequently applied as part of a single inspection set (e.g. a master profile) and together they can report all interesting cases of feature duplication without doublereporting any conditions. The Complete Duplicates inspection will never report conditions for any features that have the same unique identifier (those will be reported by this inspection). The inspection Complete Duplicates  Same UFI/GFID/FLDBID/UID can be manually configured to identify any two features that share unique identifier, feature type (FCODE), geometry and attribution (including attribute values). In the illustration, GAIT has identified a case where line Road and Cart Track features share exactly the same unique identifier (a UID in the example case). The condition is described in the condition's detailed information window and highlighted in red on the main screen. These two features would not be reported by the Complete Duplicates inspection or the Complete Duplicates  Same UFI/GFID/FLDBID/UID inspection because they have different feature types.

Both of these inspections are frequently applied as part of a single inspection set (e.g. a master profile) and together they can report all interesting cases of feature duplication without doublereporting any conditions. The Complete Duplicates inspection will never report conditions for any features that have the same unique identifier (those will be reported by this inspection). The inspection Complete Duplicates  Same UFI/GFID/FLDBID/UID can be manually configured to identify any two features that share unique identifier, feature type (FCODE), geometry and attribution (including attribute values). In the illustration, GAIT has identified a case where line Road and Cart Track features share exactly the same unique identifier (a UID in the example case). The condition is described in the condition's detailed information window and highlighted in red on the main screen. These two features would not be reported by the Complete Duplicates inspection or the Complete Duplicates  Same UFI/GFID/FLDBID/UID inspection because they have different feature types.

AC:

This KER shall display Magnitude (number of parts), FID, Feature Name (with FCODE).
This KER shall return shapefile(s) with FID, Feature Name, FCODE and location.
details.new_value:
*Acceptance Criteria:*
* This KER shall display Magnitude (number of parts), FID, Feature Name (with FCODE).
* This KER shall return shapefile(s) with FID, Feature Name, FCODE and location.

+*Notes:*+
*Area River feature that includes two parts*
This inspection can be applied to any area feature to identify those that include more than a specified number of parts. The number of parts that comprise an individual feature is defined in the input (source) data from which GAIT constructs its project. (Note that inner rings and outer rings are not different parts unless they are so designated in the input data.) When input data has more than a single part, GAIT preserves that information so that the multi-part features can be identified. The above example illustrates GAIT identification of a single area River feature that includes two parts. Each of the parts will be listed as an individual condition in the list of specific conditions and each part will contribute to the number of identified conditions. That is, this single River feature would result in two multi-part area feature conditions, both of which would be tallied in the total number of conditions and both of which will have the same magnitude. As each part is an individual condition listed in the specific conditions list, each part can be described individually, as shown above. The condition magnitude is 2 as the River feature has two parts. One of the two parts is described in the conditions detailed information window. The several parts of the same feature are always listed consecutively in the list of conditions. Note that both parts are highlighted on the main screen. The feature part corresponding to the illustrated specific condition is drawn using a bold red line to distinguish it from the other parts of the same feature. Parts that are not selected will be drawn in red, but not bold red.
MULTIPARTA.JPG

details.name: description
details.old_value:
__AC:

This KER shall display FID, Feature Name (with FCODE).
This KER shall return shapefile(s) with FID, Feature Name, FCODE and geom
details.new_value:
*Acceptance Criteria:*++

This KER shall display FID, Feature Name (with FCODE).
This KER shall return shapefile(s) with FID, Feature Name, FCODE and geom

*Notes:*++
*Completely duplicated line Road features*
This inspection can be applied to any point, line or area feature to identify those cases where the feature (as described by the primary participant specification) is geometrically duplicated by a second feature AND those two features have exactly the same attributes and attribute values as well. Complete duplicates are geometric duplicates that also duplicate their feature types and attribution (e.g., FCODE, geometry, attributes and attribute values); the features are indistinguishable, with the possible exception of unique identifiers. In fact, an exception occurs when two complete duplicate features also have the same unique identifier (e.g., GFID, UID, etc.). Complete duplicates are not reported here when the features concerned have the same identification number. These features are reported by both the Complete Duplicates  Same UFI/GFID/FLDBID/UID and the Any Two Features With The Same Identifier inspections. Note that both the Complete Duplicates inspection and the Any Two Features With The Same Identifier inspection are used very frequently. Thus, they have been specifically implemented to avoid multiple reports of the same conditions during their coordinated use. In the illustration, GAIT has identified a case where two line Road features share exactly the same location and attribution. The condition is described in the condition's detailed information window and highlighted in red on the main screen. Note that this inspection has also been engineered to function cooperatively with the Geometric Duplicate inspection. Complete Duplicate conditions will not be reported as Geometric Duplicate conditions (even though Complete Duplicate features have identical geometry). Also note that GAIT uses only one of the completely duplicated features in subsequent analyses in an effort to reduce presentation of conditions that arise simply from feature duplication, even when the Complete Duplicates inspection has not been activated.

Complete duplicates are not reported here when the features concerned have the same identification number. These features are reported by both the Complete Duplicates  Same UFI/GFID/FLDBID/UID and the Any Two Features With The Same Identifier inspections. Note that both the Complete Duplicates inspection and the Any Two Features With The Same Identifier inspection are used very frequently. Thus, they have been specifically implemented to avoid multiple reports of the same conditions during their coordinated use. In the illustration, GAIT has identified a case where two line Road features share exactly the same location and attribution. The condition is described in the condition's detailed information window and highlighted in red on the main screen. Note that this inspection has also been engineered to function cooperatively with the Geometric Duplicate inspection. Complete Duplicate conditions will not be reported as Geometric Duplicate conditions (even though Complete Duplicate features have identical geometry). Also note that GAIT uses only one of the completely duplicated features in subsequent analyses in an effort to reduce presentation of conditions that arise simply from feature duplication, even when the Complete Duplicates inspection has not been activated.

details.new_value:
*Acceptance Criteria:*

* This KER shall display FID, Feature Name (with FCODE).
* This KER shall return shapefile(s) with FID, Feature Name, FCODE and location of the duplication
* See documentation for each KER

+*Notes:*+
*Area Building feature includes three consecutive duplicate vertices*
This inspection can be applied to any line or area features to detect those features that include consecutive vertices that are duplicates in (x,y,z) for 3D features or in (x,y) for 2D features. Note that the first and last nodes (closing node for area features) are not considered consecutive by this inspection, so that line and area features having the same coordinate as their first and last (again, the closing node of an area feature) nodes will not generate a duplicate vertex condition; however, a feature having the same coordinate for their first two or last two vertices (here, including an area feature closing vertex as one of the two), or any consecutive pair between them, would result in a duplicate vertex condition. The above example illustrates detection of a Building area feature having three duplicate vertices (vertices numbered 4, 5 and 6 are identical, as shown in the Information window above). The condition's detailed information window explains the condition and lists the vertex that is duplicated. That vertex is also circled in red on the main screen. The information mode window is also illustrated after information mode has been used to query the area feature and list all its vertices. Note that the zero-length segments caused by consecutive duplicate vertices are reported by this inspection, but not by the Short Length Between Feature Vertices inspection, as an effort to avoid reporting the same condition by two different inspections. Thus, if it is necessary to find all line or area features with segments of length less than 1 meter, both this inspection and the Short Length Between Feature Vertices inspection must be applied, since only the Duplicate Vertices inspection will report segments of zero length.
V_DUPS.JPG
