subject: Build File Upload View

details.name: description
details.old_value:
*As A*  QAC User
*I want* to be able to navigate to Start a New QAC
*So that* I can upload a new file

*Given* I want to upload a file
*When*  I am on the Start a New QAC Page

journals.notes:
Story 51157 was rejected due to the links not having spaces between them... 

These stories probably were a little misleading, as the focus of 51157 was essentially just about the QAC duck logo and QAC label, while 51154 is about the nav links that will be used in the header nav bar and 51155 is about the nav bar/link use and styling. So, when we did 51157, the links were included as a scaffolding for the follow-on stories, as opposed to being the expected / final implementation.

Long story short, I think 51157 should be good to go as is, if that all seems reasonable for you

-Matt Van Slyke

*And* when I hover over a link, the link changes to a hover state

journals.notes:
All PostGIS methods are referenced in the document linked below.
Each feature contains information about the geometry object that can be retrieved with SQL queries.

To find the coordinates for a feature, you can use ST_AsGeoJSON(geom) to retrieve the type of feature and coordinates representing it.
Possibly no work is needed for the frontend to display the geometry information.

For trying to find center points of geom objects, multiple methods need to be used based on geom type:
* Polygon: ST_PointOnSurface(geom)
* LineString: ST_LineInterpolatePoint(geom, fraction)
* Point: ST_AsGeoJSON(geom)

subject: Update backend to handle .zip files created on Windows

details.name: description
details.old_value: *Acceptance Criteria:*
details.new_value:
*Acceptance Criteria:*
As a Windows user,
I want to be able to upload .zip files created on a Windows OS without getting an erroneous error message,
So that I can verify the quality of the data.

AC #1
Given I create a .zip file on Windows containing a single folder with all the shapefiles inside that folder,
When I upload the data in the proper format to QAC,
Then I should get a list of the precheck conditions, and I should NOT get a 406 error.

AC #2 (do not break existing functionality)
Given I create a .zip file on Mac OSX containing a single folder with all the shapefiles inside that folder,
When I upload the data in the proper format to QAC,
Then I should get a list of the precheck conditions, and I should NOT get a 406 error.

-LBNDUSHT - magnitude in meters- (moved to March)
MULTIPART - Magnitude in number of parts
                     Made assumption that the magnitude is the (total) number of parts - based upon GAIT 26 Inspection document; The other option would be the number of inspections minus the expected value but seemed to be the former based upon the GAIT document.
Note:
C_DUPS, V_DUPS, FEATNOTCUT, OBJECTWITHOUT, ANY_SAMEID - do not have Magnitude

-LBNDUSHT - magnitude in meters- (moved to March)
MULTIPART - Magnitude in number of parts
                     Made assumption that the magnitude is the (total) number of parts - based upon GAIT 26 Inspection document; The other option would be the number of inspections minus the expected value but seemed to be the former based upon the GAIT document.
Note:
C_DUPS, V_DUPS, FEATNOTCUT, OBJECTWITHOUT, ANY_SAMEID - do not have Magnitude

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a QAC user who has KER conditions
I want the KER magnitude to be included in the conditions .csv report
So that the magnitude is included in the conditions

AC: #1
Given I have KER conditions
When I am on the KER conditions page and I select the button
Then a .csv file containing the KER conditions can be downloaded
And the magnitude will be included in the conditions download

*Acceptance Criteria:*
* Display magnitude conditions in .csv file when downloaded
* Identify which KERs apply to this?
*Magnitude should be blank, if null, and will not display anything in that column in the table within the UI
*Create a string and add the unit in the string (it will either be blank (if null) or a space with something added. Different types (meters, degrees, ratio, and/or number)

*Notes:* 
* A magnitude is sent back no matter what, either null or the magnitude
* there is magnitude details in the attached spreadsheet. Each KER that has magnitude included is listed in the second tab of the spreadsheet. The KERs listed on that tab are sorted by release date.

subject: When KERs fail to run, an error message is displayed

details.name: subject
details.old_value: KER processing issues: How will this be handled?
details.new_value: UX: KER processing issues: How will this be handled?

details.name: description
details.old_value: Acceptance Criteria needed
details.new_value:
*As a* Qac User who is running KERs
*I want* to see error reporting if any KERs were unable to run at all
*So that* if there is an issue with any KERs running in the backend I know which KERs did not run.

*Given* The user has selected to run KERs
*When* one or more KERs fails to run
*Then* an error message is displayed above the results table displaying KERs that did run

Title: The following KERs could not run.
Description: List of the KER titles that did not run.
CTA: Start Over (button back to file upload)

*Needs Design*

subject: SPIKE: How do we handle canceling the backend process when KER process is running?

details.name: description
details.old_value: Acceptance Criteria needed
details.new_value:
Acceptance Criteria:

*Given* A QAC user is running a KER
*When* The user has exited the browser window with a currently running process
*Then* The process should stop running in the backend.

subject: Browser notification when closing the tab (cmd w || ctrl w || Pressing Back Button)

details.name: subject
details.old_value: Browser notification when closing the tab (88 w/ control window)
details.new_value: Browser notification when closing the tab (cmd w || ctrl w)

details.name: description
details.old_value: Acceptance Criteria needed
details.new_value:
As a QAC User who is running files through the QAC application
I want a check that will ask me if I want to close the tab/window while Schema Checks or Kers are running
So that I do not accidentally close the tab/window while I am running Schema Checks or Kers and lose my progress.

Given I have tried to close the tab or window
When I am running a Schema Check or Kers
Then the browser opens a notification asking me if I am sure that I want to close the tab while the process is still running knowing that I will not be able to get back to the results.

Zeplin Link: https://app.zeplin.io/project/5dc2d833a1fc3c2347277907/screen/5dd2fc77ec8a4d62bca589e5

journals.notes:
Custom text is not supported across browsers when the alert is thrown so the default "Are you sure you want to leave this page?" text will appear (copy is different across browsers).

Just to note, we were not able to add in a test at all. In order to test the functionality we had to add the functionality into the test. Because of that, the test would still pass even if it was removed from the browser. See Nichole with questions.

subject: [Tech Debt] Add logging to the current app that conforms to ICS 500-27

details.name: description
details.old_value:
What to log: * Authentication Events (logon, logoff) * Object events: CRUD and Permission/Ownership Modifications * External Communications * System Events (reboot, shutdown, etc.) Log Entry requirements: * Date and time using ISO 8601 (YYYYMMDD hh:mm:ss.fffff) * Source of the event (IP, host, etc.) * Subject or actor (user, service, etc.) * Object (business entity, file, etc.) * Type of event (login, download, etc.) * Outcome: success or failure Example of log object: 

{
  date_time: 20190603T13:44:13Z,
  app_name: APP,
  log_level: INFO,
  source: 0.0.0.0,
  type: login,
  actor: 61334,
  object: account,
  outcome: failure
}

Standard: https://www.dni.gov/files/documents/FOIA/DF-2016-00213.pdf What to log: * Authentication Events (logon, logoff) * Object events: CRUD and Permission/Ownership Modifications * External Communications * System Events (reboot, shutdown, etc.) Log Entry requirements: * Date and time using ISO 8601 (YYYYMMDD hh:mm:ss.fffff) * Source of the event (IP, host, etc.) * Subject or actor (user, service, etc.) * Object (business entity, file, etc.) * Type of event (login, download, etc.) * Outcome: success or failure Example of log object: 

{
  date_time: 20190603T13:44:13Z,
  app_name: APP,
  log_level: INFO,
  source: 0.0.0.0,
  type: login,
  actor: 61334,
  object: account,
  outcome: failure
}

BUG: Precheck (schema) conditions are displaying good and bad data

details.name: description
details.old_value:
Acceptance Criteria:
*The precheck schema conditions are returning both good and bad features for each shapefile that has a problem. Note: A shapefile can contain multiple features. When there is a condition within the shapefile, it is returning ll of the features, even if some of them are "good." 
*In order to test this, look at the database shapefile table that is created or open the shapefile and queue GIS. There is a text field in the shapefile that shows "good" data or "bad" data. If good data is visible, it should be removed from populating.
*  Compare to the report on the screen.
details.new_value:
Acceptance Criteria:
*The precheck schema exceptions are returning both good and bad features for each shapefile that has a problem. Note: A shapefile can contain multiple features. When there is a exception within the shapefile, it is returning all of the features, even if some of them are "good." 
*In order to test this, look at the database shapefile table that is created or open the shapefile in QGIS. There is a text field in the shapefile that shows "good" data or "bad" data. If good data is visible, it should be removed from populating.
*  Compare to the report on the screen.

*Notes:
* On the precheck screen, within the table, currently there are both good and bad features displaying. Good features should not display.*

journals.notes:
* Ran multiple precheck datasets through GAIT and QAC and received different outputs on both tools
* GAIT display only bad data and QAC still displayed good and bad data 
* Will follow up with which data was utilized to test the bug on 24NOV19

QAC reports:

725238E9-CAEA-4177-A106-6E00526A0D51
725238E9-CAEA-4177-A106-6E00526A0D46, and 
1 Zero-Part Area/Line
725238E9-CAEA-4177-A106-6E00526A0D55_AAQ130.shp

Appears QAC is reporting all AAQ130 features, though only 1 is bad.

*precheck_fcode_errors.zip:*
GAIT reports:
4 erros, (ABJ100, expected BJ100; and, and PBH120, expected BH120)

QAC reports:

A4A03722-CF9B-43CB-BB8F-7E45E7091E79_PBH120

It appears that QAC is finding the errors, but reporting them as bad FCODEs.

LAN010 GAN attribute (expected Real, got Integer)
LAN050 GAN attribute (expected Real, got Integer)

QAC reports:

But does report the following, which are actually allowed column names (reporting good data)

NAM
NFI
NFN

Appears to be working, but results are stated incorrectl:y Stated as 'Blank Attribute'.

journals.notes:
Not sure about the value of this story. The "Save as" dialog is a function of the browser and dependent upon user settings: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42967050/html5-a-download-force-save-as-dialogue

If the user wishes to change the filename, they can do so at an OS level from their download folder after download.

-BD

Needs discussion whether or not this is needed. Not a defined user pattern and not consistent with cross platforms and browsers (works on edge, not chrome or IE). 
See Nichole if you have questions.

*AND* Clicking on a KER in the side nav will show the conditions in a table for that KER
*AND* The results view contains a table for each KER with the columns "Feature Name", "FID" and "FCode", and conditionally "Tolerance"
*AND* The user can display the KERs conditions by either KER name or feature name 
*AND* The user can click a link to find more information about the KER
*AND* The user can select the download button to download all KER Conditions by either .csv, and/or .shp

Additional Acceptance Criteria:
* Ideation
* Wire Frames

Note:
If you have questions reach out to UX Team. 

**Conditional until after Ideation session. (Wireframe TBD)

subject: Standardize Drop Down Button Component

details.name: description
details.old_value:
Acceptance Criteria:
*
details.new_value:
Acceptance Criteria:
* There is a component that outputs a button with a dropdown menu
* The button has the default button class from USWDS set so there is styling already applied when the component is used
* It should allow for additional classes to be passed through
* It should require display text for the button
* It should allow functions to be passed through the onClick attribute on the button
* It should display the menu when the button is clicked
* It should hide the dropdown menu when a menu item is clicked

*So that* I can download the Schema Check results

*Given* I have Schema Check conditions
*When* I select on the download results button
*Then* a .csv file containing the Schema Check conditions is downloaded
*And* the button is using the button component.

Given I have Ker Check conditions
When I click on the download Ker report button
Then a .csv file containing the Ker conditions is downloaded
And the button is using the button component.

Given I have uploaded a valid zip file
When I click the new dataset button
Then I am returned to the upload screen
And the button is using the button component.

Given I have uploaded a valid zip file
When I click on the continue button
Then my kers are processed
And I am taken to the Ker result page
And the button is using the button component

Additional information:
See Designs here:  https://zpl.io/VY1lQnm

Acceptance Criteria:
* refactor to the USWDS standards

* The KER conditions in the .csv will contain the headers and data (verify fields and contents of file)

Notes:
Need to determine what will happen when there are not any KER conditions (should we disable the button, etc.)?

journals.notes: Roy and Erik.

QUESTIONS:

1. Do we need success notification(style and verbiage) 
2. Do we need error notification(style and verbiage) 
3. Should we disable/hide download button and or create spinner during csv download
4. When no ker data is present should the button be disabled or hidden

Callout:
We had a turnaround to discuss the size of this story. We feel that we should have a discussion about breaking this story into multiple stories given the amount of work involved in completing the ACs as written. Possibly we could complete this story by just including currently accessible ker data in the csv(fcode, fid).

QUESTION Regarding CSV Data Format:
How do we display data for a case where there are multiple FIDs for a given condition?  Do we store data in CSV the same way as it is displayed on the KER Results page - multiple FIDs per condition? OR should it be a separate row for each FID?

details.new_value:
*As a* QAC user who has Pre-check conditions
*I want* readable Pre-check names in the Pre-check page side nav
*So That* I can recognize which Pre-checks have conditions
 
*Given* I have Pre-check
*When* I am on the Pre-check page
*Then* display the Pre-checks without underscores 
*And* in title case.

For example: Currently Pre-checks are displayed with underscores: filename_geometry_mismatch.  We want to display as: Filename Geometry Mismatch.

*Notes: 
Discussion with Matt Van Slyke: In the prechecks, there is a "false" and "true" column identifier when a precheck has a condition. Can this be used versus just not displaying any "positive" conditions? For the UI, we need all of the columns to display, even if there aren't conditions. Please chat with Matt Van Slyke if there are questions.*

*Questions:*
# Can we get a list of the precheck names so Jeff can scan them to validate the only thing changing is removing the underscores

Answer:
Please use the Schema/Pre-check names from the attached spreadsheet (MGCP Pre-checks.xlsx).

NOTES:
Style Guide: https://designsystem.digital.gov/components/typography/
Design: https://www.figma.com/file/GJHlW6USIwySfwe0F7T4Z5/NGA-Slices?node-id=339%3A3

subject: UI SIDE NAV: Number of Errors per Pre-check AND Kers

details.name: description
details.old_value:
*As a* user who has pre-check errors
*I want* to see a label next to the Pre-check name
*So that* I know the total number of errors for that particular pre-check

*Given* I am on the pre-check page
*When* I have pre-check errors
*Then* I see a label with the total next to the pre-check name

*See Designs here:*
* https://www.figma.com/file/GJHlW6USIwySfwe0F7T4Z5/NGA-Slices?node-id=635%3A2165

*Notes:*
* The label does not truncate
* The label is a fixed distance from the dividing line (i.e. if the column width is adjusted the tag will stay fixed to the right)
* Government style guide does have a 'label' element
details.new_value:
*As a* user who has pre-check errors
*I want* to see a label with the total number of errors next to the Pre-check name
*So that* I know the total number of errors for that particular pre-check

*Given* I am on the pre-check page
*When* I have pre-check errors
*Then* I see a label with the total next to the pre-check name

*See Designs here:*
* https://www.figma.com/file/GJHlW6USIwySfwe0F7T4Z5/NGA-Slices?node-id=635%3A2165

*Notes:*
* If  KER has multiple parts than the "total" is the sum off all of the parts
* The label does not truncate
* The label is a fixed distance from the dividing line (i.e. if the column width is adjusted the tag will stay fixed to the right)
* Government style guide does have a 'label' element

details.new_value:
*As a* QAC user who has pre-check errors
*I want* to see the number of errors each Pre-check has
*So that* I know the total number of errors for each particular pre-check
 
*Given* I have pre-check errors
*When* upon the pre-check page load
*Then* I see a label with the total number or errors next to the pre-check in the navigation bar
*See Designs here:*
* https://www.figma.com/file/GJHlW6USIwySfwe0F7T4Z5/NGA-Slices?node-id=635%3A2165
 
*Notes:*
* If we use the same logic for KERS as we are writing for pre-checks, keep in mind -  if KER has multiple parts than the "total" is the sum off all of the parts
* The label does not truncate
* The label is a fixed distance from the dividing line (i.e. if the column width is adjusted the tag will stay fixed to the right)
* Government style guide does have a 'label' element
 
Government Style Guide:
https://designsystem.digital.gov/components/sidenav/

* The label is a fixed distance from the dividing line (i.e. if the column width is adjusted the tag will stay fixed to the right)
* Government style guide does have a 'label' element

journals.notes:
Notes to help devs (THEY MAY BE OUT OF DATE OR COMPLETELY WRONG)

Hi Roy and Marc!!! Hopefully this is helpful :)

1. These changes will be in the backend (python code)
2. Make sure to add tests to precheck.feature and ker.feature. Use a test file with a nested structure. (You could probably make this yourself by unzipping one of the existing test zips and adding a nested folder)
3. Current flow for prechecks: prechecks() in api/precheck.py -> run_prechecks() in PrecheckEngine.py -> open_zip() in PrecheckEngine.py
4. Current flow for kers: check_kers() in api/ker.py -> ingest() in IngestionEngine.py -> shapefile_to_db() in IngestionEngine.py
5. We currently use helper functions to unzip a zip and get shapefiles from a directory in IngestionEngineHelpers.py
6. If you get lost, add debug points and step through the flow.

subject: KER: VVTERR3WAY Single Feature Meeting 3 Specific Specifications (needs edit)

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the Single Feature Meeting 3 Specific Specifications KER with report (VVTERR3WAY) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with VVTERR3WAY errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing VVTERR3WAY errors.

Given a data set without VVTERR3WAY errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no VVTERR3WAY errors

Notes: 
Identify (1) features with the same NFI and NFN attributes but with different NAM attributes, (2) features from different feature classes with identical NFI, NFN, and NAM, (3) point features from the same feature class with identical NFI, NFN, and NAM.
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are VVTERR3WAY in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- BaDGer to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (VVTERR3WAY KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to any point, line or area feature to identify those individual features that meet the requirements described by all of the primary, secondary and tertiary participant specifications. This use of the participant specifications is unlike that of any other GAIT inspections.  Typically, each specification will be applied to a different feature.  As used here, the participant specifications function more like parameters to a query.  They instruct GAIT to identify single features that meet the specifications for all three participants.

Note that only the first occurrence of a specific condition will be reported for each feature.  Also, area feature cut-outs will not be considered by this inspection.

I want to run the Single Feature Meeting 2 Specific Specifications KER with report (VVTERR2WAY) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

AC #1:
Given a data set with VVTERR2WAY errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see an output showing VVTERR2WAY errors.

AC #2:
Given a data set without VVTERR2WAY errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see an output showing no VVTERR2WAY errors

AC #3:
Given I have conditions
When I view the results
Then the KER shall display Condition Number, Feature Name, and FCODE,
AND,
Then the KER shall return shapefile(s) with UUID, Feature Name, FCODE and location.

Notes: 
*- Query is in GitLab*
- Output refers to both results and report


Identify 

(1) violations of the ""MGCP_IllogicalAttributeEnumeration_V11_TRD4.xlsx"" document, distributed with GAIT, 



(2) any feature with a populated VOI value and a sentinel HGT value, and, 



(3) any Sand Dune feature with a SDT != 'Unknown' and SDO != 'Not Applicable' ('-32765') or 'Unknown' ('-32767').



- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are VVTERR2WAY in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- BaDGer to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (VVTERR2WAY KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to any point, line or area feature to identify individual features that meet the requirements described by both the primary and secondary participant specifications. This use of the participant specifications is unlike that of any other GAIT inspections.  Typically, the specifications will be applied to different features.  As used here, the participant specifications function more like parameters to a query.  They instruct GAIT to identify single features that meet the specifications for both participants

Note that only the first occurrence of a specific condition will be reported for each feature.  Also, area feature cut-outs will not be considered by this inspection.

subject: SPIKE! Single Feature Meeting Specific Specification KER with report (VVTERR1WAY)

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the Single Feature Meeting Specific Specification KER with report (VVTERR1WAY) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with VVTERR1WAY errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing VVTERR1WAY errors.

Given a data set without VVTERR1WAY errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no VVTERR1WAY errors

Notes: 
Identify (1) violations of specifications in the "MGCP_NumericValueRange_V5_TRD4.xls" spreadsheet, distributed with GAIT, (2) any point Built-Up Area, Settlement, or Named Location feature with NAM = "Unknown", "UNKNOWN", "UNK", "Unk", "unk", "Not Applicable", "NOT APPLICABLE", "N_A", "n_a", "NA", or "na", (3) any area Soil Surface Region feature with SMC = "Salt", (4) any area Rock Formation feature with RKF = "Pinnacle", (5) violations of the "MGCP_IllogicalAttributeEnumeration_V11_TRD4.xlsx" document, distributed with GAIT, (6) features with TRS attributes that are not consistent with EG CR #165, (7) area tidal Water features with NAM = "Unknown", "UNKNOWN", "UNK", "Unk", "unk", "Not Applicable", "NOT APPLICABLE", "N_A", "n_a", "NA", or "na", "Not Populated", "NP", "N_P", "n_p", "np", "NOT POPULATED", "Null", "N/A", or "NULL".
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are VVTERR1WAY in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- BaDGer to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (VVTERR1WAY KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to any point, line or area feature to identify those individual features that simply meet the requirements described by the primary participant specifications. This use of the participant specifications is atypical of GAIT inspections.  Typically, the specifications are used to specify which features will have geometric relationships or other requirements applied.  As used here, the participant specifications function more like parameters to a query.  They instruct GAIT to identify single features that meet the specifications of the primary participant specifications.

Note that only the first occurrence of a specific condition will be reported for each feature. Also, area feature cut-outs will not be considered by this inspection.

GAIT can automatically generate an inspection specification file that can be used to identify any feature having a 3D vertex where the elevation value is greater than or equal to 46.0 m.  Unlike other automatically-generated inspection specification files where the inspection short name is part of the file name, this file is named HGT_OVER_46m.txt.  It can be loaded into GAIT to perform the associated inspection regardless of the schema used to create the project.

subject: KER: COVERFAIL

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the 100% Area Coverage Failure KER with report (COVERFAIL) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with COVERFAIL errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing COVERFAIL errors.

Given a data set without COVERFAIL errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no COVERFAIL errors

Notes: 
Identify any edges of Landcover Area Features that are not covered by exactly one edge of other Landcover Area Features.  Edges that are closer than 0.1m to the closest whole degree line to the project boundary are not reported.
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are COVERFAIL in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- BaDGer to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (COVERFAIL KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to identify locations that are covered either by zero or by more than one area features described by the primary participant specification (these are the Land Cover class features defined in the MGCP TRD).  Violations occur when either no specified area feature or more than one specified area feature covers some portion of the project area.  Examples of both these circumstances are illustrated above (the white area corresponds to part of the project that is not covered by any area feature and the brown area between the two red lines corresponds to a part of the project that is covered by more than one land cover area feature).

GAIT identifies these conditions by first forming a set consisting of each edge of the specified area features; then, it matches pairs of edges in the set.  When an edge cannot be matched by only one other edge, either a hole or an overlap must exist.  After all possible matches have been made, GAIT gathers the unmatched and overmatched (more than one match) edges into connected groups and reports one condition for each connected group.  Another unique aspect of this inspection is that multiple features almost always contribute to a single condition, and there is no single feature that defines a hole or overlap. Thus, all exported edges in one condition contribute to the same problem, but there is no feature-unique information that can be associated with the condition (e.g., feature type, layer, etc.).  Also, at least one group of unmatched edges could always exist, corresponding to the feature edges defining the outside edges of the project.  GAIT attempts to suppress reporting these unmatched edges by referencing the primary and secondary tolerances that have been specified.

The default specifications for both the primary and secondary tolerances are tailored to inspections that would be applied to a standard-production 1-degree MGCP cell.  Both settings are used in the process of suppressing reports of conditions on the extreme boundaries of the project data.  The primary tolerance provides a method to specify the latitude and longitude of the outer edges of the project.  The primary tolerance is used to specify the cell size in increments of 0.125 degrees; the default setting of 1.0 indicates that the inspection should be tailored to whole degree cells.   Using this setting, any unmatched edge that overlaps a multiple of 1.0 degrees (e.g., whole degrees) in latitude or longitude will not be reported as a condition.  The secondary tolerance is used to define acceptable proximity to the latitudes and longitudes determined by the primary tolerance.  If any area feature perimeter edge is within the secondary tolerance (in meters) to a line of latitude or longitude defined by the primary tolerance, and that line of latitude or longitude is an outer edge of the project, then no 100% Area Coverage Failure condition will be reported based on that edge. 
 
These tolerance specifications can be used to isolate small coordinate mismatches in production regions smaller than an entire 1-degree cell.  When the default tolerances are used, conditions will likely be reported all around the sub-degree cell extreme boundary, since no area feature edges are within 0.1 meters of a whole degree of latitude or longitude.  However, the tolerance specifications can be changed to better suit the production cell.  As an example, if data is being produced in 1/8 degree increments, the primary tolerance can be set to 0.125 to suppress condition reports around the 1/8 degree cell boundary.  In this case, no area feature edge within 0.1 meters of any multiple of 1/8 degree in latitude or longitude, that also defines an outer edge of the project data, will be reported as a condition.  Using 0.125 as the primary tolerance, but changing the secondary tolerance from 0.1 (default value) to 0.001 produces the report illustrated below.  These settings identify very small coordinate errors.
details.new_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the 100% Area Coverage Failure KER with report (COVERFAIL) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with COVERFAIL errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing COVERFAIL errors.

Given a data set without COVERFAIL errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no COVERFAIL errors

Notes: 
- Query needs to be written
Identify any edges of Landcover Area Features that are not covered by exactly one edge of other Landcover Area Features.  Edges that are closer than 0.1m to the closest whole degree line to the project boundary are not reported.
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are COVERFAIL in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- BaDGer to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (COVERFAIL KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to identify locations that are covered either by zero or by more than one area features described by the primary participant specification (these are the Land Cover class features defined in the MGCP TRD).  Violations occur when either no specified area feature or more than one specified area feature covers some portion of the project area.  Examples of both these circumstances are illustrated above (the white area corresponds to part of the project that is not covered by any area feature and the brown area between the two red lines corresponds to a part of the project that is covered by more than one land cover area feature).

GAIT identifies these conditions by first forming a set consisting of each edge of the specified area features; then, it matches pairs of edges in the set.  When an edge cannot be matched by only one other edge, either a hole or an overlap must exist.  After all possible matches have been made, GAIT gathers the unmatched and overmatched (more than one match) edges into connected groups and reports one condition for each connected group.  Another unique aspect of this inspection is that multiple features almost always contribute to a single condition, and there is no single feature that defines a hole or overlap. Thus, all exported edges in one condition contribute to the same problem, but there is no feature-unique information that can be associated with the condition (e.g., feature type, layer, etc.).  Also, at least one group of unmatched edges could always exist, corresponding to the feature edges defining the outside edges of the project.  GAIT attempts to suppress reporting these unmatched edges by referencing the primary and secondary tolerances that have been specified.

The default specifications for both the primary and secondary tolerances are tailored to inspections that would be applied to a standard-production 1-degree MGCP cell.  Both settings are used in the process of suppressing reports of conditions on the extreme boundaries of the project data.  The primary tolerance provides a method to specify the latitude and longitude of the outer edges of the project.  The primary tolerance is used to specify the cell size in increments of 0.125 degrees; the default setting of 1.0 indicates that the inspection should be tailored to whole degree cells.   Using this setting, any unmatched edge that overlaps a multiple of 1.0 degrees (e.g., whole degrees) in latitude or longitude will not be reported as a condition.  The secondary tolerance is used to define acceptable proximity to the latitudes and longitudes determined by the primary tolerance.  If any area feature perimeter edge is within the secondary tolerance (in meters) to a line of latitude or longitude defined by the primary tolerance, and that line of latitude or longitude is an outer edge of the project, then no 100% Area Coverage Failure condition will be reported based on that edge. 
 
These tolerance specifications can be used to isolate small coordinate mismatches in production regions smaller than an entire 1-degree cell.  When the default tolerances are used, conditions will likely be reported all around the sub-degree cell extreme boundary, since no area feature edges are within 0.1 meters of a whole degree of latitude or longitude.  However, the tolerance specifications can be changed to better suit the production cell.  As an example, if data is being produced in 1/8 degree increments, the primary tolerance can be set to 0.125 to suppress condition reports around the 1/8 degree cell boundary.  In this case, no area feature edge within 0.1 meters of any multiple of 1/8 degree in latitude or longitude, that also defines an outer edge of the project data, will be reported as a condition.  Using 0.125 as the primary tolerance, but changing the secondary tolerance from 0.1 (default value) to 0.001 produces the report illustrated below.  These settings identify very small coordinate errors.

*As a* QAC user with a data set
*I want* to run an inspection on COVERFAIL
*So that* I am notified if COVERFAIL has any errors

AC #1
*Given* I have a data set with COVERFAIL errors
*When* an Inspection is run on COVERFAIL
*Then* I expect to see an error if there are any edges of Landcover Area Features that are not covered by exactly one edge of other Landcover Area Features.  Edges that are closer than 0.1m to the closest whole degree line to the project boundary are not reported.

For testing purposes:
We expect to see ???? errors for the COVERFAIL ker, as specified by Geobadger test data.

AC #2
*Given* I have a test dataset without errors
*When* I run an inspection on COVERFAIL
*Then* I expect to see 0 COVERFAIL errors in my output

AC #3
Given I am in the QAC app
*When* I load a data set with COVERFAIL errors
Then I see COVERFAIL displayed by its full name: 100% Area Coverage Failure

Product notes:
**Identify any edges of Landcover Area Features that are not covered by exactly one edge of other Landcover Area Features.  Edges that are closer than 0.1m to the closest whole degree line to the project boundary are not reported.
** For any features listed in the acceptance criteria, insert specific FID
** Specify the number of expected errors to get for testing for each KER part

details.name: description
details.old_value:
*As a* QAC user with a data set
*I want* to run an inspection on COVERFAIL
*So that* I am notified if COVERFAIL has any errors

AC #1
*Given* I have a data set with COVERFAIL errors
*When* an Inspection is run on COVERFAIL
*Then* I expect to see an error if there are any edges of Landcover Area Features that are not covered by exactly one edge of other Landcover Area Features.  Edges that are closer than 0.1m to the closest whole degree line to the project boundary are not reported.

For testing purposes:
We expect to see ???? errors for the COVERFAIL KER, as specified by Geobadger test data.

AC #2
*Given* I have a test dataset without errors
*When* I run an inspection on COVERFAIL
*Then* I expect to see 0 COVERFAIL errors in my output

AC #3
Given I am in the QAC app
*When* I load a data set with COVERFAIL errors
Then I see COVERFAIL displayed by its full name: 100% Area Coverage Failure

Product notes:
**Identify any edges of Landcover Area Features that are not covered by exactly one edge of other Landcover Area Features.  Edges that are closer than 0.1m to the closest whole degree line to the project boundary are not reported.
** For any features listed in the acceptance criteria, insert specific FID
** Specify the number of expected errors to get for testing for each KER part

subject: Area Edge Not Covered By Area Edge Or Line Segment KER with report (ANOCOVERLA)

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the Area Edge Not Covered By Area Edge Or Line Segment KER with report (ANOCOVERLA) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with ANOCOVERLA errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing ANOCOVERLA errors.

Given a data set without ANOCOVERLA errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no ANOCOVERLA errors

Notes: 
Identify: (1) any area Island feature not 100% covered (surrounded) by area Island, Tidal Water, Void Collection Area, Aqueduct, or perennial area {Canal, Ditch, Lake, Reservoir, or River} features, (2) any area Tidal Water feature not covered (surrounded) by area Tidal Water, Training Wall, Breakwater, Berthing Structure, Void Collection Area, Canal, Ditch, River, Aqueduct, Lake, or Reservoir features or line Training Wall, Breakwater, Berthing Structure, Land Water Boundary, Seawall features, (3) any area Tidal Water or perennial River, Ditch, Lake, or Reservoir cut-out not filled with an area Island, Void Collection Area, or same-feature type feature (0.1m tolerances).
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are ANOCOVERLA in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- BaDGer to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (ANOCOVERLA KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to identify area feature outer rings (primary participant specification) or area feature inner rings (cut-outs, the secondary participant specification) that have perimeter edges which are not within the specified tolerance (distance in meters) to a second line feature or area feature perimeter (tertiary participant specification).

In this use, covered by indicates that the area feature perimeter segment and comparable portion of the tertiary participant feature have coordinates that are less than the specified (tolerance) distance apart.  This inspection can be applied to features of any dimension, but the distance calculations are always performed in 2D.  The distance tolerance can be set to zero.

This inspection can be configured to ignore conditions on the extreme boundaries of a project.  See an earlier section of this document, Conditions on the Project Outer Edges for more information on the operation and use of this filtering capability.

(2) any area Tidal Water feature not covered (surrounded) by area Tidal Water, Training Wall, Breakwater, Berthing Structure, Void Collection Area, Canal, Ditch, River, Aqueduct, Lake, or Reservoir features or line Training Wall, Breakwater, Berthing Structure, Land Water Boundary, Seawall features, 
*-39- 52 errors*

(3) any area Tidal Water or perennial River, Ditch, Lake, or Reservoir cut-out not filled with an area Island, Void Collection Area, or same-feature type feature (0.1m tolerances).
-30 errors- getting new dataset, will need to determine number of errors

*Remaining work for ANOCOVERLA* (as of 24 Jan 2020)

 Update Part 3 SQL for proper distance measurements, if needed (see PLLPROXFAIL)
 Refactor unionMissingColumns code in the build_out_input_permutations method ker_wrapper.py. this code is very similar to the union code in the same method.
 Get additional test data for part 3 when layer A is filled (within tolerance) but not touching but another feature from the same layer
> * This has already been requested via the geobadger channel in rocketchat
 Once the additional data is requested, the final part of the SQL of part 3 will need to be updated to check for good cases from the previous bullet
> * _NOTE_, if the data is significantly different from existing test data set, the expected number of conditions may change
 _NOTE_: the expected number of conditions in the story are wrong. With the existing dataset, I would trust the expected number of conditions in the Behave tests. The story can be updated as needed. Of course, we need to make sure that the POs agree with the numbers that we came up with.



+Existing Notes+
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are ANOCOVERLA in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- BaDGer to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (ANOCOVERLA KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to identify area feature outer rings (primary participant specification) or area feature inner rings (cut-outs, the secondary participant specification) that have perimeter edges which are not within the specified tolerance (distance in meters) to a second line feature or area feature perimeter (tertiary participant specification).

In this use, covered by indicates that the area feature perimeter segment and comparable portion of the tertiary participant feature have coordinates that are less than the specified (tolerance) distance apart.  This inspection can be applied to features of any dimension, but the distance calculations are always performed in 2D.  The distance tolerance can be set to zero.

This inspection can be configured to ignore conditions on the extreme boundaries of a project.  See an earlier section of this document, Conditions on the Project Outer Edges for more information on the operation and use of this filtering capability.

subject: Area Not Covered by Area KER with report (ANOCOVERA)

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the Area Not Covered by Area KER with report (ANOCOVERA) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with ANOCOVERA errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing ANOCOVERA errors.

Given a data set without ANOCOVERA errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no ANOCOVERA errors

Notes: 
Identify: (1) any area Stopway feature that is not completely inside an area Aerodrome feature, (2) any area Runway, Taxiway or Apron feature not completely inside an area Aerodrome or Heliport feature,  (3) any area Rapids feature not completely inside an area River feature, (4) any area Forest Clearing feature not completely inside an area Wood or Thicket feature.
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are ANOCOVERA in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- BaDGer to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (ANOCOVERA KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to identify area features (described by the primary participant specification) that are not fully contained (in 2D) by a single instance of a second area feature (described by the secondary participant specification).  This inspection can be applied to features of any dimension, but the containment determination is always made using 2D calculations.   Any point inside or along an edge of the primary participant that is not contained in a single instance of the secondary participant will result in a condition.  That is, if two or more area features satisfy the secondary participant requirements and together, as a group, they fully cover the primary participant area feature, GAIT will report a condition unless a single secondary participant, by itself, fully covers the primary participant.

That is, if two or more area features satisfy the secondary participant requirements and together, as a group, they fully cover the primary participant area feature, GAIT will report a condition unless a single secondary participant, by itself, fully covers the primary participant.

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the Two Lines Overlap (Coincident Segments) KER with report (SHARESEG) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with SHARESEG errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing SHARESEG errors.

Given a data set without SHARESEG errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no SHARESEG errors

Notes: 
- Identify: (1) any line Bridge feature coincident with a line Road or Cart Track feature where the Bridge feature has a WID less than the Road or Cart Track feature's WD1 value (only values between 0m and 900m are considered); (2) any line Bridge feature coincident with a Road or Cart Track feature where the Bridge feature and the Road or Cart Track feature have WD1 values between 0m and 900m but the values are not the same; (3) any line Road or Railway without LOC = 'Below Ground Surface' not inside an area Building coincident with a Tunnel feature; (4) any line Road, Railway, or Pipeline without LOC = 'Above Surface' coincident with a line Bridge feature; (5) any line Road or Cart Track feature with ACC = 'Accurate' coincident with a line Tunnel feature; (6) any line Cart Track or Trail feature without WTC = "Fair-weather" coincident with a line River feature but not coincident with a line Ford or Bridge feature, (7) any line Bridge feature that does not have FUN = "Destroyed" that is coincident with a line Road feature that has a different FUN than the line Bridge feature, (8) all specifications in the "MGCP_IllogicalSharedLines_V13_TRD4.xls" spreadsheet, distributed with GAIT, (9) any line Bridge feature coincident with a line Road or Cart Track feature where one of the features has WD1=-32767 and the other does not, (10) any line railway Bridge feature with WD1 not equal to the GAW a coincident line Railway or Railway Sidetrack feature, (11) any line Tunnel, Dam, Cut, Causeway Structure, Embankment, or Bridge with TRS = "Not Applicable" that overlaps a line Road, Railway, Railway Sidetrack, Cart Track, Trail, Aqueduct, Canal, or Pipeline feature, (12) any line Bridge, Causeway Structure, Tunnel, Dam, Embankment, or Cut feature without TRS= "Other" overlapping a carried feature that does not correspond to the assigned TRS, (13) any line Bridge, Causeway Structure, Tunnel, Dam, Embankment, or Cut feature with TRS= "Other" overlapping exactly one carried feature type.
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are SHARESEG in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- BaDGer to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (SHARESEG KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to any area feature to identify those cases where the feature (described by the primary participant specification) has a portion of its perimeter that forms a kink or kickback, as determined by applying an angular criterion.  GAIT will skip over consecutive, duplicate vertices when applying this inspection.  Consecutive duplicate vertices are considered another type of condition (Duplicate Vertices) and inappropriate for use in this test.

To detect these conditions, GAIT measures the angle between consecutive segments along the perimeter of area features (in 2D).  A condition is reported when the angle equals or exceeds the specified tolerance. This inspection can be configured to ignore conditions on the extreme boundaries of a project.  See an earlier section of this document, Conditions on the Project Outer Edges for more information on the operation and use of this filtering capability.

AC #3:
Given I have conditions
When I view the results
Then the KER shall display Magnitude (meters to 6th decimal), Condition Number, Feature Names, and FCODEs,
AND,
Then the KER shall return shapefile(s) with Magnitude (meters to 6th decimal), UUIDs, Feature Names, FCODEs and location.

Notes: 
*- Query is in work*
- Output refers to both results and report


- Identify: 
(1) any line Bridge feature coincident with a line Road or Cart Track feature where the Bridge feature has a WID less than the Road or Cart Track feature's WD1 value (only values between 0m and 900m are considered); 
*2 errors*


(2) any line Bridge feature coincident with a Road or Cart Track feature where the Bridge feature and the Road or Cart Track feature have WD1 values between 0m and 900m but the values are not the same; 
*2 errors*


(3) any line Road or Railway without LOC = 'Below Ground Surface' not inside an area Building coincident with a Tunnel feature; 
*2 errors*


(4) any line Road, Railway, or Pipeline without LOC = 'Above Surface' coincident with a line Bridge feature; 
*3 errors*


(5) any line Road or Cart Track feature with ACC = 'Accurate' coincident with a line Tunnel feature; 
*2 errors*


(6) any line Cart Track or Trail feature without WTC = "Fair-weather" coincident with a line River feature but not coincident with a line Ford or Bridge feature, 
*2 errors*


(7) any line Bridge feature that does not have FUN = "Destroyed" that is coincident with a line Road feature that has a different FUN than the line Bridge feature, 
*1 error*


(8) all specifications in the "MGCP_IllogicalSharedLines_V13_TRD4.xls" spreadsheet, distributed with GAIT, 
*1592 errors*


(9) any line Bridge feature coincident with a line Road or Cart Track feature where one of the features has WD1=-32767 and the other does not, 
*4 errors*


(10) any line railway Bridge feature with WD1 not equal to the GAW a coincident line Railway or Railway Sidetrack feature, 
*2 errors*


(11) any line Tunnel, Dam, Cut, Causeway Structure, Embankment, or Bridge with TRS = "Not Applicable" that overlaps a line Road, Railway, Railway Sidetrack, Cart Track, Trail, Aqueduct, Canal, or Pipeline feature, 
*48 errors*


(12) any line Bridge, Causeway Structure, Tunnel, Dam, Embankment, or Cut feature without TRS= "Other" overlapping a carried feature that does not correspond to the assigned TRS, 
*840 errors*


(13) any line Bridge, Causeway Structure, Tunnel, Dam, Embankment, or Cut feature with TRS= "Other" overlapping exactly one carried feature type.
*84 errors*

subject: KER: AREAKINK

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the Area Kink / Kickback (AREAKINK) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with AREAKINK errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing AREAKINK errors.

Given a data set without AREAKINK errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no AREAKINK errors

Notes: 
- Identify any feature coordinates that lie outside the whole degree latitude or longitude lines.
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are AREAKINK in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- Someone to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (AREAKINK KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- Simple React app 
- Flash as backend
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to any area feature to identify those cases where the feature (described by the primary participant specification) has a portion of its perimeter that forms a kink or kickback, as determined by applying an angular criterion. Consecutive duplicate vertices are considered another type of condition (Duplicate Vertices) and inappropriate for use in this test.

To detect these conditions, GAIT measures the angle between consecutive segments along the perimeter of area features (in 2D).  A condition is reported when the angle equals or exceeds the specified tolerance. This inspection can be configured to ignore conditions on the extreme boundaries of a project.  See an earlier section of this document, Conditions on the Project Outer Edges for more information on the operation and use of this filtering capability.

*When* I load a data set with AREAKINK errors
*Then* I see AREAKINK displayed by its full name: Area Kink / Kickback 

AC #4:
Given I have conditions
When I view the results
Then the KER shall display Magnitude (degrees to 6th decimal), Condition Number, Feature Name, and FCODE,
AND,
Then the KER shall return shapefile(s) with Magnitude (degrees to 6th decimal), UUID, Feature Name, FCODE and location.

Product notes:
*- Query is in GitLab*
- Identify any area feature containing consecutive perimeter segments forming an angle >= 175 degrees.
- For any features listed in the acceptance criteria, insert specific FID

*From GAIT26:* 
This inspection can be applied to any area feature to identify those cases where the feature (described by the primary participant specification) has a portion of its perimeter that forms a kink or kickback, as determined by applying an angular criterion.  GAIT will skip over consecutive, duplicate vertices when applying this inspection.  Consecutive duplicate vertices are considered another type of condition (Duplicate Vertices) and inappropriate for use in this test.

To detect these conditions, GAIT measures the angle between consecutive segments along the perimeter of area features (in 2D).  A condition is reported when the angle equals or exceeds the specified tolerance. This inspection can be configured to ignore conditions on the extreme boundaries of a project.  See an earlier section of this document, Conditions on the Project Outer Edges for more information on the operation and use of this filtering capability.

AREAKINK:

Part.......Good.......Bad.....Total
_________________________
...1..........1.........1.........2
_________________________
.Sum..........1.........1.........2

subject: KER: LOOPS

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the Loop (Self-intersecting Area Or Line Feature) (LOOPS) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with LOOPS errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing LOOPS errors.

Given a data set without LOOPS errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no LOOPS errors

Notes: 
- Identify any feature coordinates that lie outside the whole degree latitude or longitude lines.
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are LOOPS in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- Someone to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (LOOPS KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- Simple React app 
- Flash as backend
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to any line or area feature to identify those cases where the feature (described by the primary participant specification) forms a loop by intersecting itself.  The test for self-intersection excludes possible intersections that involve the first and last vertices (end nodes) of both line and area features.  This implies that line features having either a first or last (or both) vertex that is coincident with another vertex or segment on that feature will NOT be reported by this inspection.  The related inspection Line Feature Loop (any type) will report all types of line feature loops including those involving either terminal vertex. This inspection can be applied to both 2D and 3D features, but the intersection calculation will always be made in 2D.  Note that GAIT will only report one loop condition per feature regardless of the number of loops contained in the feature.

- Identify any self-intersecting area or line feature (except line Racetrack features).
- For any features listed in the acceptance criteria, insert specific FID
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to any line or area feature to identify those cases where the feature (described by the primary participant specification) forms a loop by intersecting itself.  The test for self-intersection excludes possible intersections that involve the first and last vertices (end nodes) of both line and area features.  This implies that line features having either a first or last (or both) vertex that is coincident with another vertex or segment on that feature will NOT be reported by this inspection.  The related inspection Line Feature Loop (any type) will report all types of line feature loops including those involving either terminal vertex. This inspection can be applied to both 2D and 3D features, but the intersection calculation will always be made in 2D.  Note that GAIT will only report one loop condition per feature regardless of the number of loops contained in the feature.

subject: KER: KICKBACK

details.name: subject
details.old_value: Line Kickback KER with report
details.new_value: Line Kickback KER with report (KICKBACK)

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the Line Kickback (KICKBACK) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with KICKBACK errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing KICKBACK errors.

Given a data set without KICKBACK errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no KICKBACK errors

Notes: 
- Identify any feature coordinates that lie outside the whole degree latitude or longitude lines.
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are KICKBACK in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- Someone to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (KICKBACK KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- Simple React app 
- Flash as backend
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to any line feature to identify those cases where the feature (as described by the primary participant specification) forms a kickback (180 kink condition) along its own length. GAIT recognizes kickback conditions as Line Kink (Single Feature) conditions that have a magnitude of 180; thus, there is no user-specified tolerance for the Kickback inspection.

Duplicated features will not cause reports of kickbacks, even though they do form one kind of instance of this condition.  That is, when two features have overlapping segments, they could be seen as forming a kickback.  These kinds of constructions can be identified by applying the inspection Two Lines Overlap (Coincident Segments).

- Identify any line feature where consecutive line segments form an angle of 180 degrees.
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are KICKBACK in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- BaDGer to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (KICKBACK KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to any line feature to identify those cases where the feature (as described by the primary participant specification) forms a kickback (180 kink condition) along its own length. GAIT recognizes kickback conditions as Line Kink (Single Feature) conditions that have a magnitude of 180; thus, there is no user-specified tolerance for the Kickback inspection.

Duplicated features will not cause reports of kickbacks, even though they do form one kind of instance of this condition.  That is, when two features have overlapping segments, they could be seen as forming a kickback.  These kinds of constructions can be identified by applying the inspection Two Lines Overlap (Coincident Segments).

subject: KER: CONTEXT_KINK

details.name: subject
details.old_value: Line Feature Join Kink KER with report
details.new_value: Line Feature Join Kink KER with report (CONTEXT_KINK)

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the Line Feature Join Kink (CONTEXT_KINK) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with CONTEXT_KINK errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing CONTEXT_KINK errors.

Given a data set without CONTEXT_KINK errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no CONTEXT_KINK errors

Notes: 
- Identify any feature coordinates that lie outside the whole degree latitude or longitude lines.
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are CONTEXT_KINK in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- Someone to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (CONTEXT_KINK KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- Simple React app 
- Flash as backend
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to any line features to identify those cases where the feature (described by the primary participant specification) forms a kink when it intersects with (connects to) another line feature (also described by the primary participant specification).  Also, one of the features must have two segments immediately preceding the segment participating in forming the kink and these two segments form an angle >= 45.0.  The primary and secondary tolerances are angular measures (specified in degrees) that define a range for the kink itself (the tolerances do not influence the 45.0 heading change requirement).  Note that GAIT does not include kickbacks (180 kinks) in the conditions reported by this inspection.

This inspection is intended to be applied simultaneously with the inspections Z Shaped Line Kink, Line Kink (Single Feature) and Line Kink.  The default tolerance values of these four inspections have been tailored so that no single inspection will report the same condition as any of the others.   The specific conditions are sorted by magnitude and those conditions with the highest angles are presented first to aid in the review process.

- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to any line features to identify those cases where the feature (described by the primary participant specification) forms a kink when it intersects with (connects to) another line feature (also described by the primary participant specification).  Also, one of the features must have two segments immediately preceding the segment participating in forming the kink and these two segments form an angle >= 45.0.  The primary and secondary tolerances are angular measures (specified in degrees) that define a range for the kink itself (the tolerances do not influence the 45.0 heading change requirement).  Note that GAIT does not include kickbacks (180 kinks) in the conditions reported by this inspection.

This inspection is intended to be applied simultaneously with the inspections Z Shaped Line Kink, Line Kink (Single Feature) and Line Kink.  The default tolerance values of these four inspections have been tailored so that no single inspection will report the same condition as any of the others.   The specific conditions are sorted by magnitude and those conditions with the highest angles are presented first to aid in the review process.

details.old_value: Line Kink (Single Feature) KER with report
details.new_value: Line Kink (Single Feature) KER with report (INTERNALKINK)

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the Line Kink (Single Feature)  (INTERNALKINK) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with INTERNALKINK errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing INTERNALKINK errors.

Given a data set without INTERNALKINK errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no INTERNALKINK errors

Notes: 
- Identify any feature coordinates that lie outside the whole degree latitude or longitude lines.
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are INTERNALKINK in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- Someone to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (INTERNALKINK KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- Simple React app 
- Flash as backend
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to any line feature to identify those cases where the feature (described by the primary participant specification) includes a kink along its own length.  The criterion is an angular measure, specified in degrees.  Note that GAIT does not include kickbacks (180 kinks) in the conditions reported by this inspection.

This inspection is intended to be applied simultaneously with the inspections Line Kink, Z Shaped Line Kink and Line Feature Join Kink.  The default tolerance values of these four inspections have been tailored so that no single inspection will report the same condition as any of the others.   The specific conditions are sorted by magnitude and those conditions with the highest angles are presented first to aid in the review process.

details.name: description
details.old_value:
*As a* QAC user with a data set 
*I want* to run an inspection on INTERNALKINK
*So that* I am notified if INTERNALKINK has any errors

AC #1: 
*Given* I have a test data set with INTERNALKINK errors
*When* I run an inspection on INTERNALKINK
*Then* I expect to see an error if any line feature feature containing consecutive segments that form an angle that is >= 165 degrees and < 178 degrees.

For testing purposes:
We expect to see *<XXX>* errors for the INTERNALKINK KER, as specified by Geobadger test data

AC #2:
*Given* I have a test data set without INTERNALKINK errors
*When* I run an inspection on INTERNALKINK
*Then* I expect to see 0 INTERNALKINK errors in my output

AC #3:
*Given* I am in the QAC app
*When* I load a data set with INTERNALKINK errors
*Then* I see INTERNALKINK displayed by its full name: Line Kink

Product notes:
*- Query is in GitLab*
- Identify any line feature feature containing consecutive segments that form an angle that is >= 165 degrees and < 178 degrees.
- For any features listed in the acceptance criteria, insert specific FID
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to any line feature to identify those cases where the feature (described by the primary participant specification) includes a kink along its own length.  The criterion is an angular measure, specified in degrees.  Note that GAIT does not include kickbacks (180 kinks) in the conditions reported by this inspection.
This inspection is intended to be applied simultaneously with the inspections Line Kink, Z Shaped Line Kink and Line Feature Join Kink.  The default tolerance values of these four inspections have been tailored so that no single inspection will report the same condition as any of the others.   The specific conditions are sorted by magnitude and those conditions with the highest angles are presented first to aid in the review process.

subject: KER: Z_KINK

details.name: subject
details.old_value: 'Z' shaped Line Kink KER with report
details.new_value: 'Z' shaped Line Kink KER with report (Z_KINK)

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the 'Z' shaped Line Kink (Z_KINK) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with Z_KINK errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing Z_KINK errors.

Given a data set without Z_KINK errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no Z_KINK errors

Notes: 
- Identify any feature coordinates that lie outside the whole degree latitude or longitude lines.
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are Z_KINK in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- Someone to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (Z_KINK KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- Simple React app 
- Flash as backend
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to any line feature to identify those cases where the feature (described by the primary participant specification) forms a Z shaped kink when it connects to (end node coincidence) another line feature (also described by the primary participant specification) or along its own length.  The criterion is an angular measure, specified in degrees.   A Z shaped kink is similar to two consecutive kink conditions.  A difference between this inspection and Line Kink is that a less restrictive tolerance is useful here.  (Compare the Kinks default tolerance to the tolerance range used here.)

This inspection is intended to be applied simultaneously with the inspections Line Kink, Line Kink (Single Feature) and Line Feature Join Kink.  The default tolerance values of these four inspections have been tailored so that no single inspection will report the same condition as any of the others.   The specific conditions are sorted by magnitude and those conditions with the highest angles are presented first to aid in the review process.

- Identify any line feature or pair of joined line features of same feature type where three consecutive segments form two angles that are >= 135 degrees and < 160 degrees. The value of the larger angle is reported as the magnitude of the condition.
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are Z_KINK in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- BaDGer to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (Z_KINK KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to any line feature to identify those cases where the feature (described by the primary participant specification) forms a Z shaped kink when it connects to (end node coincidence) another line feature (also described by the primary participant specification) or along its own length.  The criterion is an angular measure, specified in degrees.   A Z shaped kink is similar to two consecutive kink conditions.  A difference between this inspection and Line Kink is that a less restrictive tolerance is useful here.  (Compare the Kinks default tolerance to the tolerance range used here.)

This inspection is intended to be applied simultaneously with the inspections Line Kink, Line Kink (Single Feature) and Line Feature Join Kink.  The default tolerance values of these four inspections have been tailored so that no single inspection will report the same condition as any of the others.   The specific conditions are sorted by magnitude and those conditions with the highest angles are presented first to aid in the review process.

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the Line Kink (KINK) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with KINK errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing KINK errors.

Given a data set without KINK errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no KINK errors

Notes: 
- Identify any feature coordinates that lie outside the whole degree latitude or longitude lines.
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are KINK in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- Someone to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (KINK KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- Simple React app 
- Flash as backend
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to any line feature to identify those cases where the feature (described by the primary participant specification) forms a kink at the point where either of its end nodes connect to another line feature (also described by the primary participant specification) or along its own length.  The criterion is an angular measure, specified in degrees.  Note that GAIT does not include kickbacks (180 kinks) in the conditions reported by this inspection.

This inspection is intended to be applied simultaneously with the inspections Z Shaped Line Kink, Line Kink (Single Feature) and Line Feature Join Kink.  The default tolerance values of these four inspections have been tailored so that no single inspection will report the same condition as any of the others.  The specific conditions are sorted by magnitude and those conditions with the highest angles are presented first to aid in the review process.

- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- Simple React app 
- Flash as backend
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to any line feature to identify those cases where the feature (described by the primary participant specification) forms a kink at the point where either of its end nodes connect to another line feature (also described by the primary participant specification) or along its own length.  The criterion is an angular measure, specified in degrees.  Note that GAIT does not include kickbacks (180 kinks) in the conditions reported by this inspection.

This inspection is intended to be applied simultaneously with the inspections Z Shaped Line Kink, Line Kink (Single Feature) and Line Feature Join Kink.  The default tolerance values of these four inspections have been tailored so that no single inspection will report the same condition as any of the others.  The specific conditions are sorted by magnitude and those conditions with the highest angles are presented first to aid in the review process.
