We expect to see *<XXX>* errors for the KINK KER, as specified by Geobadger test data

AC #2:
*Given* I have a test data set without KINK errors
*When* I run an inspection on KINK
*Then* I expect to see 0 KINK errors in my output

AC #3:
*Given* I am in the QAC app
*When* I load a data set with KINK errors
*Then* I see KINK displayed by its full name: Line Kink

Product notes:
*- Query is in GitLab*
- Identify any line feature or pair of joined line features of same feature type where consecutive or joined line segments form an angle >= 178 degrees.
- For any features listed in the acceptance criteria, insert specific FID
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to any line feature to identify those cases where the feature (described by the primary participant specification) forms a kink at the point where either of its end nodes connect to another line feature (also described by the primary participant specification) or along its own length.  The criterion is an angular measure, specified in degrees.  Note that GAIT does not include kickbacks (180 kinks) in the conditions reported by this inspection.
     This inspection is intended to be applied simultaneously with the inspections Z Shaped Line Kink, Line Kink (Single Feature) and Line Feature Join Kink.  The default tolerance values of these four inspections have been tailored so that no single inspection will report the same condition as any of the others.  The specific conditions are sorted by magnitude and those conditions with the highest angles are presented first to aid in the review process.

subject: KER: PLLPROXFAIL

details.name: subject
details.old_value: Point - Feature Intersection Coincidence Failure KER with report
details.new_value: Point - Feature Intersection Coincidence Failure KER with report (PLLPROXFAIL)

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the Point - Feature Intersection Coincidence Failure (PLLPROXFAIL) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with PLLPROXFAIL errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing PLLPROXFAIL errors.

Given a data set without PLLPROXFAIL errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no PLLPROXFAIL errors

Notes: 
- Identify any feature coordinates that lie outside the whole degree latitude or longitude lines.
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are PLLPROXFAIL in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- Someone to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (PLLPROXFAIL KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- Simple React app 
- Flash as backend
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to any point features to identify those cases where the point feature (described by the primary participant specification) is more than the specified distance away from an intersection of two line or area features (specified as the secondary and tertiary participants).  The distance measurement will be made in 2D.
details.new_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the Point - Feature Intersection Coincidence Failure (PLLPROXFAIL) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with PLLPROXFAIL errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing PLLPROXFAIL errors.

Given a data set without PLLPROXFAIL errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no PLLPROXFAIL errors

Notes: 
- Identify (1) any point Ford feature not within 0.1m of the intersection of a line Road, Cart Track, or Trail and a line Aqueduct, Canal, Ditch, or River feature; (2) any point Road Interchange feature that is not within 0.1m of an intersection of two line Road features with RST = 'Hard/Paved' and WTC = 'All Weather'.
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are PLLPROXFAIL in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- Someone to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (PLLPROXFAIL KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- Simple React app 
- Flash as backend
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to any point features to identify those cases where the point feature (described by the primary participant specification) is more than the specified distance away from an intersection of two line or area features (specified as the secondary and tertiary participants).  The distance measurement will be made in 2D.

subject: KER: FEATOUTSIDE

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the Feature Coordinate Outside Whole-Degree Project Boundaries (FEATOUTSIDE) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with FEATOUTSIDE errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing FEATOUTSIDE errors.

Given a data set without FEATOUTSIDE errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no FEATOUTSIDE errors

Notes: 
- Identify any feature coordinates that lie outside the whole degree latitude or longitude lines
 tell you if there are FEATOUTSIDE in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- Someone to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (FEATOUTSIDE KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- Simple React app
- Flash as backend
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to identify any vertices of point, area or line features (described
by the primary participant specification) that lie outside the whole-degree boundaries of the
project. This inspection can be applied to either 2D or 3D features; however, the outside test is
always applied as a 2D test. The inspection first calculates the whole-degree latitude parallels
and longitude meridians that are closest to the maximum and minimum longitude and latitude
coordinates of features included in the project. Then it compares the latitude and longitude
coordinates of each feature vertex (described by the primary participant specification) to identify
those that are (a) greater than the maximum parallel or meridian or (b) less than the minimum
parallel or meridian, and are more than tolerance distance from that parallel or meridian.

This inspection is intended for application to projects having outer boundaries that should align
to whole degree lines of latitude and longitude, such as an MGCP one-degree cell. The
inspection may return unwanted results when applied to projects that are not designed to align
with whole-degree lines of latitude and longitude.

those that are (a) greater than the maximum parallel or meridian or (b) less than the minimum
parallel or meridian, and are more than tolerance distance from that parallel or meridian.

This inspection is intended for application to projects having outer boundaries that should align
to whole degree lines of latitude and longitude, such as an MGCP one-degree cell. The
inspection may return unwanted results when applied to projects that are not designed to align
with whole-degree lines of latitude and longitude.

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the Feature Coordinate Outside Whole-Degree Project Boundaries (FEATOUTSIDE) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with FEATOUTSIDE errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing FEATOUTSIDE errors.

Given a data set without FEATOUTSIDE errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no FEATOUTSIDE errors

Notes: 
- Query needs to be written
- Identify any feature coordinates that lie outside the whole degree latitude or longitude lines (tolerance = 0m).
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are FEATOUTSIDE in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- BaDGer to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (FEATOUTSIDE KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to identify any vertices of point, area or line features (described
by the primary participant specification) that lie outside the whole-degree boundaries of the
project. This inspection can be applied to either 2D or 3D features; however, the outside test is
always applied as a 2D test. The inspection first calculates the whole-degree latitude parallels
and longitude meridians that are closest to the maximum and minimum longitude and latitude
coordinates of features included in the project. Then it compares the latitude and longitude
coordinates of each feature vertex (described by the primary participant specification) to identify
those that are (a) greater than the maximum parallel or meridian or (b) less than the minimum
parallel or meridian, and are more than tolerance distance from that parallel or meridian.

This inspection is intended for application to projects having outer boundaries that should align
to whole degree lines of latitude and longitude, such as an MGCP one-degree cell. The
inspection may return unwanted results when applied to projects that are not designed to align
with whole-degree lines of latitude and longitude.

subject: KER: AWITHOUTA

details.name: subject
details.old_value: Area Not Fully Containing Second Feature KER with report
details.new_value: Area Not Fully Containing Second Feature KER with report (AWITHOUTA)

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the Area Not Fully Containing Second Feature (AWITHOUTA) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with AWITHOUTA errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing AWITHOUTA errors.

Given a data set without AWITHOUTA errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no AWITHOUTA errors

Notes: 
- Identify: (1) Any area Aerodrome feature with FPT = 'Major' that does not completely contain at least one area Runway feature with LEN = [910 - 12000] and RST = 'Hard/Paved'; (2) any area Aerodrome feature with FPT = 'Minor and Hard' that does not completely contain at least one area Runway feature with LEN = [10 - 910]; (3) any area Aerodrome feature with FPT = 'Minor and Soft' that does not completely contain at least one area Runway feature that is not attributed RST = 'Hard/Paved'; and, (4) any area Aerodrome feature with FPT = 'Unknown' or 'Other' that does not completely contain at least one area Runway feature.
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are OBJECTWITHOUT in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- Someone to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (OBJECTWITHOUT KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- Simple React app
- Flash as backend
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to identify any area feature (described by the primary participant
specification) that does not fully contain any point, line or area features (described by the
secondary participant specification) or mask (grid) post value (described by the secondary
participant specification and the primary and secondary tolerance specifications) inside its
perimeter. This inspection can be applied to either 2D or 3D features; however, the contain
test is always applied as a 2D test. Also, the contained area feature may share some or all
edges with the containing feature, but if any edge of the secondary participant lies outside of
the primary participant, the secondary feature is not considered to be contained by the primary
participant.
When a mask (grid geometry) has been specified as a secondary participant, the primary
participant area feature must contain at least one mask post where the value at that post is in the
range defined by the primary and secondary tolerance specifications. This capability allows
GAIT to identify Aerodrome area features that do not contain at least one appropriate Edit Mask
post value, a requirement of the TREx program.

Notes: 
*- Query is in GitLab*
- Identify: (1) Any area Aerodrome feature with FPT = 'Major' that does not completely contain at least one area Runway feature with LEN = [910 - 12000] and RST = 'Hard/Paved'; (2) any area Aerodrome feature with FPT = 'Minor and Hard' that does not completely contain at least one area Runway feature with LEN = [10 - 910]; (3) any area Aerodrome feature with FPT = 'Minor and Soft' that does not completely contain at least one area Runway feature that is not attributed RST = 'Hard/Paved'; and, (4) any area Aerodrome feature with FPT = 'Unknown' or 'Other' that does not completely contain at least one area Runway feature.
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are OBJECTWITHOUT in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- BaDGer to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (OBJECTWITHOUT KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to identify any area feature (described by the primary participant
specification) that does not fully contain any point, line or area features (described by the
secondary participant specification) or mask (grid) post value (described by the secondary
participant specification and the primary and secondary tolerance specifications) inside its
perimeter. This inspection can be applied to either 2D or 3D features; however, the contain
test is always applied as a 2D test. Also, the contained area feature may share some or all
edges with the containing feature, but if any edge of the secondary participant lies outside of
the primary participant, the secondary feature is not considered to be contained by the primary
participant.
When a mask (grid geometry) has been specified as a secondary participant, the primary
participant area feature must contain at least one mask post where the value at that post is in the
range defined by the primary and secondary tolerance specifications. This capability allows
GAIT to identify Aerodrome area features that do not contain at least one appropriate Edit Mask
post value, a requirement of the TREx program.

As a QAC user with a dataset 
I want to run an inspection on AWITHOUTA
So that I am notified if my parts has any errors related to AWITHOUTA

AC #1: 
Given I have a test dataset with errors
When I run an inspection on AWITHOUTA
Then I expect to only see parts with errors related to my dataset 

(Example: If 5 out of 10 parts have errors, display only those 5 parts on output)

For testing purposes, each part should appear on the output with the specified number of errors (totaling x errors):

Any area Land Aerodrome (GB005) feature with FPT = 'Major' (1) that does not completely contain at least one area Runway feature (GB055) with LEN = [910 - 12000] and RST = 'Hard/Paved' (1)
Any area Land Aerodrome(GB005) feature with FPT = 'Minor and Hard' (2) that does not completely contain at least one area Runway feature (GB055) with LEN = [10 - 910]
Any area Land Aerodrome (GB005)  feature with FPT = 'Minor and Soft' (3) that does not completely contain at least one area Runway feature (GB055) that is not attributed RST = 'Hard/Paved'
Any area Land Aerodrome  (GB005) feature with FPT = 'Unknown' (0) or 'Other' (999) that does not completely contain at least one area Runway feature (GB055) 

AC #2: 
Given I have a test dataset without errors
When I run an inspection on AWITHOUTA
Then I expect to see 0 AWITHOUTA errors in my output

subject: [CODE REVIEW] (OBJECTWITHOUT) Area Not Containing Any Part Of Another Feature KER with report

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the Area Not Containing Any Part Of Another Feature (OBJECTWITHOUT) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with OBJECTWITHOUT errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing OBJECTWITHOUT errors.

Given a data set without OBJECTWITHOUT errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no OBJECTWITHOUT errors

Notes: 
- Identify: (1) Any area Dam, Embankment, or Transportation Station feature with TRS = 'Railway' that does not contain a line Railway or Railway Sidetrack feature; (2) any area Dam or Embankment feature with TRS = 'Road' that does not contain a line Road or Cart Track feature; (3) any area Dam or Embankment feature with TRS = 'Aqueduct' that does not contain any part of a line or area Aqueduct feature; (4) any area Dam or Embankment feature with TRS = 'Canal' that does not contain any part of a line or area Canal feature; (5) any area Dam or Embankment feature with TRS = 'Pipeline' that does not contain a line Pipeline feature; (6) any area Bridge, Dam, Embankment, or Tunnel feature with TRS = 'Other' that does not coincide with a line Aqueduct, Canal, Cart Track, Pipeline, Railway, Railway Sidetrack, Road, Trail, or, area Aqueduct or Canal feature; (7) any area Transportation Station feature with TRS = 'Road' not containing a line Road feature; and, (8) any area Transportation Station feature with TRS = 'Other' not containing a line Railway, Railway Sidetrack, or Road feature.
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are OBJECTWITHOUT in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- Someone to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (OBJECTWITHOUT KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- Simple React app
- Flash as backend

Then I see a report showing no OBJECTWITHOUT errors

Notes: 
- Identify: (1) Any area Dam, Embankment, or Transportation Station feature with TRS = 'Railway' that does not contain a line Railway or Railway Sidetrack feature; (2) any area Dam or Embankment feature with TRS = 'Road' that does not contain a line Road or Cart Track feature; (3) any area Dam or Embankment feature with TRS = 'Aqueduct' that does not contain any part of a line or area Aqueduct feature; (4) any area Dam or Embankment feature with TRS = 'Canal' that does not contain any part of a line or area Canal feature; (5) any area Dam or Embankment feature with TRS = 'Pipeline' that does not contain a line Pipeline feature; (6) any area Bridge, Dam, Embankment, or Tunnel feature with TRS = 'Other' that does not coincide with a line Aqueduct, Canal, Cart Track, Pipeline, Railway, Railway Sidetrack, Road, Trail, or, area Aqueduct or Canal feature; (7) any area Transportation Station feature with TRS = 'Road' not containing a line Road feature; and, (8) any area Transportation Station feature with TRS = 'Other' not containing a line Railway, Railway Sidetrack, or Road feature.
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are OBJECTWITHOUT in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- Someone to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (OBJECTWITHOUT KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- Simple React app
- Flash as backend
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to identify instances of area features (described by the primary participant specification) that do not include any point or part of a line or area feature (described by the secondary participant specification) inside their perimeter. This inspection can be applied to either 2D or 3D features; however, the inside test is always applied as a 2D test. GAIT will consider a line or area feature vertex that lies exactly on the perimeter of a qualifying area to be inside that area feature. Also, a line feature only partially inside the area feature will satisfy the requirement.

This inspection can be configured to ignore conditions on the extreme boundaries of a project. See the earlier section of this document, Conditions on the Project Outer Edges for more information on the operation and use of this filtering capability.

journals.notes:
We cannot implement this until we know if we should follow the specs that we found in gitlab or the story here. We made a spreadsheet highlighting the differences.

Both the story and the gitlab call out parts 1-5
Only the gitlab calls out 5-8
Only the story calls out 9-11

Further, for 1-5 everything is the same, EXCEPT, the story always calls out Bridges and Tunnels for layer 1 in the comparison, while the gitlab excludes bridges and tunnels.

How should we proceed?

https://gitlab.devops.geointservices.io/sfd/QAC_Checks/blob/master/MGCP-TDS_Checks/MGCP/OBJECTWITHOUT

GAIT will consider a line or area feature vertex that lies exactly on the perimeter of a qualifying area to be inside that area feature. Also, a line feature only partially inside the area feature will satisfy the requirement.

This inspection can be configured to ignore conditions on the extreme boundaries of a project. See the earlier section of this document, Conditions on the Project Outer Edges for more information on the operation and use of this filtering capability.

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the Line Feature End Node Undershoots Project Whole-Degree Boundary (LBNDUSHT) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with LBNDUSHT errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing LBNDUSHT errors.

Given a data set without LBNDUSHT errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no LBNDUSHT errors

Notes: 
- Identify disconnected line feature end nodes that undershoot the 1 degree latitude or longitude edges by 0.1m - 10m (Primary tolerance {coordinate equality limit} = 0.1m; secondary tolerance {boundary proximity limit} = 10m).
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are LBNDUSHT in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- Someone to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (LBNDUSHT KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- Simple React app
- Flash as backend
details.new_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the Line Feature End Node Undershoots Project Whole-Degree Boundary (LBNDUSHT) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with LBNDUSHT errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing LBNDUSHT errors.

Given a data set without LBNDUSHT errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no LBNDUSHT errors

Notes: 
- Identify disconnected line feature end nodes that undershoot the 1 degree latitude or longitude edges by 0.1m - 10m (Primary tolerance {coordinate equality limit} = 0.1m; secondary tolerance {boundary proximity limit} = 10m).
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are LBNDUSHT in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- Someone to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (LBNDUSHT KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- Simple React app
- Flash as backend
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to any line feature (as specified by the primary participant) to detect those with end nodes (either first or last node) that are inside the minimum and maximum, whole-degree lines of longitude and latitude that define the project and are distant from that latitude or longitude by an amount that lies within the open interval defined by the primary and secondary tolerances. That is, the end node is further away from the meridian or parallel then the distance specified as the primary tolerance and the end node to closer to the meridian or parallel
than the distance specified by the secondary tolerance.

This inspection is intended to compliment the inspection Feature Coordinate Outside Project Whole-Degree Boundaries (Containment group) by allowing a capability to identify line feature end nodes with coordinates that are very close to MGCP one-degree project boundaries, but do not exceed those boundaries.

- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are LBNDUSHT in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- BaDGer to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (LBNDUSHT KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to any line feature (as specified by the primary participant) to detect those with end nodes (either first or last node) that are inside the minimum and maximum, whole-degree lines of longitude and latitude that define the project and are distant from that latitude or longitude by an amount that lies within the open interval defined by the primary and secondary tolerances. That is, the end node is further away from the meridian or parallel then the distance specified as the primary tolerance and the end node to closer to the meridian or parallel
than the distance specified by the secondary tolerance.

This inspection is intended to compliment the inspection Feature Coordinate Outside Project Whole-Degree Boundaries (Containment group) by allowing a capability to identify line feature end nodes with coordinates that are very close to MGCP one-degree project boundaries, but do not exceed those boundaries.

KER:
upload statement created
No dependencies

From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to any line feature (as specified by the primary participant) to detect those with end nodes (either first or last node) that are inside the minimum and maximum, whole-degree lines of longitude and latitude that define the project and are distant from that latitude or longitude by an amount that lies within the open interval defined by the primary and secondary tolerances. That is, the end node is further away from the meridian or parallel then the distance specified as the primary tolerance and the end node to closer to the meridian or parallel than the distance specified by the secondary tolerance.

This inspection is intended to compliment the inspection Feature Coordinate Outside Project Whole-Degree Boundaries (Containment group) by allowing a capability to identify line feature end nodes with coordinates that are very close to MGCP one-degree project boundaries, but do not exceed those boundaries.

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the Feature Coordinate Undershoots Project Whole Degree Boundary (BNDRYUNDERSHT) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with BNDRYUNDERSHT errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing BNDRYUNDERSHT errors.

Given a data set without BNDRYUNDERSHT errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no BNDRYUNDERSHT errors

Notes: 
- Identify any feature coordinates that undershoot the 1 degree latitude or longitude edges by 0.1m or less (Primary tolerance {coordinate equality limit} = 0.1m; secondary tolerance {boundary proximity limit} = 10m).
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are BNDRYUNDERSHT in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- Someone to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (BNDRYUNDERSHT KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- Simple React app
- Flash as backend

AND,

upload statement
no dependencies

From GAIT 26: 
This inspection can be applied to any point, line or area feature vertices (as specified by the primary participant) to detect those that are inside the minimum and maximum, whole-degree lines of longitude and latitude that define the project and are distant from that latitude or longitude by an amount that lies within the open interval defined by the primary and secondary tolerances. That is, the feature vertex is further away from the meridian or parallel then the distance specified as the primary tolerance and the vertex to closer to the meridian or parallel than the distance specified by the secondary tolerance.

This inspection is intended to compliment the inspection Feature Coordinate Outside Project Whole-Degree Boundaries (Containment group) by allowing a capability to identify feature coordinates that are very close to MGCP one-degree project boundaries, but do not exceed those boundaries.

subject: KER:  CUT_INT

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the Cut-out Touches Parent Feature Outer Ring (CUT_INT) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with CUT_INT errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing CUT_INT errors.

Given a data set without CUT_INT errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no CUT_INT errors

Notes: 
- Identify any area feature cut-out that intersects (is within 0.001m of) the outer boundary of the feature.
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are CUT_INT in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- Someone to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (CUT_INT KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- Simple React app
- Flash as backend

subject: KER:  AREAUNCLOSED (Needs UTM)

details.name: description
details.old_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the Unclosed Area (AREAUNCLOSED) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with AREAUNCLOSED errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing AREAUNCLOSED errors.

Given a data set without AREAUNCLOSED errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no AREAUNCLOSED errors

Notes: 
- Identify any area feature that does not close in x, y or z (tolerance = 0.0m).
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are AREAUNCLOSED in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- Someone to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (AREAUNCLOSED KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- Simple React app
- Flash as backend
details.new_value:
As a Geospatial Data Analyst
I want to run the Unclosed Area (AREAUNCLOSED) KER in QAC and see a report
So that I know if there are errors in the data set.

Given a data set with AREAUNCLOSED errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing AREAUNCLOSED errors.

Given a data set without AREAUNCLOSED errors
When an Inspection is run on this data set
Then I see a report showing no AREAUNCLOSED errors

Notes: 
- Identify any area feature that does not close in x, y or z (tolerance = 0.0m).
- Given a data set and it's going to go through the KERs and tell you if there are AREAUNCLOSED in there. It's going to tell you via the report.
- Someone to provide given data sets with and without errors.
- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (AREAUNCLOSED KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
- Simple React app
- Flash as backend
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to detect any area features having first and last vertices that have different coordinates (any combination of difference in the X, Y or Z coordinate values). Note that there is a separate inspection (Area Not Closed in Z) that will detect area features whose first and last vertices differ only by their Z coordinate. Any condition detected by the Area Not Closed in Z will also be detected by the Unclosed Area inspection. When an area feature has different first and last coordinates, the distance between those coordinates is calculated and
compared to the specified tolerance. This distance is measured in 3D for three dimensional features and in 2D for two dimensional features. When the measured distance is greater than the specified tolerance, a condition is reported.

- Need to decide a way to run an inspection (AREAUNCLOSED KER).
- Data does not have to be uploaded by a user, it can be manually ingested by a developer into a database.
From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to detect any area features having first and last vertices that have different coordinates (any combination of difference in the X, Y or Z coordinate values). Note that there is a separate inspection (Area Not Closed in Z) that will detect area features whose first and last vertices differ only by their Z coordinate. Any condition detected by the Area Not Closed in Z will also be detected by the Unclosed Area inspection. When an area feature has different first and last coordinates, the distance between those coordinates is calculated and compared to the specified tolerance. This distance is measured in 3D for three dimensional features and in 2D for two dimensional features. When the measured distance is greater than the specified tolerance, a condition is reported.

*Then* the KER shall display Magnitude (in meters, to the 6th decimal), Condition number, Feature Name (with FCODE),
AND,
*Then* the KER shall return shapefile(s) with Magnitude (meters to 6th decimal), UUID, Feature Name, FCODE and location.

Product notes:
*- Query is in GitLab*
- Identify any area feature that does not close in x, y or z (tolerance = 0.0m). "Should have one error (and zero good rows)"
- For any features listed in the acceptance criteria, insert specific FID
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to detect any area features having first and last vertices that have different coordinates (any combination of difference in the X, Y or Z coordinate values). Note that there is a separate inspection (Area Not Closed in Z) that will detect area features whose first and last vertices differ only by their Z coordinate. Any condition detected by the Area Not Closed in Z will also be detected by the Unclosed Area inspection. When an area feature has different first and last coordinates, the distance between those coordinates is calculated and compared to the specified tolerance. This distance is measured in 3D for three dimensional features and in 2D for two dimensional features. When the measured distance is greater than the specified tolerance, a condition is reported.

--> per our last story writing meeting, we're going to punt on returning magnitude since the tolerance for this KER is zero.

*Notes from Eric*
Current state of this KER development:
There are a few PostGIS functions that return validity of a geom, and you can also get a reason if the geom is invalid.  I was using this approach and it works fine in pgadmin (postgres 11.5, postgis 2.5.2). however, when running the behave test as well as the app code, the query does not detect the given test data as invalid, because the same query in the app considers the test data to be valid (postgres 9.5, postgis 2.5.2). i  don't know why this is. i ran the app code with postgres 10, and got the same result, namely that the bad test data is not considered invalid geom, but it should be. at this point, i'm not sure what the best next step is.

*Updated Notes* (as of 18 Dec 2019, 1300)

It appears that the conversion of shapefiles to postgres tables via GDAL/OGR is automatically closing open polygons for us. While there are several options available to use for the PostgreSQL driver, we did not find one to use that would turn off auto-closing (see https://gdal.org/drivers/vector/pg.html#vector-pg). If you dig around a little in the source code for GDAL OGR (https://github.com/OSGeo/gdal/tree/master/gdal/ogr), you will see a parameter called AutoClose and a function called closeRings. So while there is some notion of control of that, it is well below the level of the Python bindings. We have thus concluded that we don't have control over the auto-close functionality, assuming we continue to use the Python GDAL/OGR package.

Furthermore, we discussed this issue with Chris Welch and Jeff Mayo. Chris was unaware of any software package that would allow geospatial analysts to create an open polygon. He had to manually open an existing data set, and edit the binary content to even generate test data for this KER. After discussing this with Jeff, he seemed open to the idea of getting rid of this KER completely. We have (maybe) one outstanding item, which is to poll the MGCP community to see if any of them are using old geospatial software. The theory is that this 'open polygon' scenario might be possible if the analysts were using really old geospatial software. Until then, this story should not be worked.



Current state of this KER development: (as of 17 Dec 2019, 0900)
There are a few PostGIS functions that return validity of a geom, and you can also get a reason if the geom is invalid.  I was using this approach and it works fine in pgadmin (postgres 11.5, postgis 2.5.2). however, when running the behave test as well as the app code, the query does not detect the given test data as invalid, because the same query in the app considers the test data to be valid (postgres 9.5, postgis 2.5.2). i  don't know why this is. i ran the app code with postgres 10, and got the same result, namely that the bad test data is not considered invalid geom, but it should be. at this point, i'm not sure what the best next step is.

Product notes:
*- Query is in GitLab*
- Identify any area feature that does not close in x, y or z (tolerance = 0.0m). "Should have one error (and zero good rows)." Qualifies as UTM.
- For any features listed in the acceptance criteria, insert specific FID
- From GAIT26: This inspection can be applied to detect any area features having first and last vertices that have different coordinates (any combination of difference in the X, Y or Z coordinate values). Note that there is a separate inspection (Area Not Closed in Z) that will detect area features whose first and last vertices differ only by their Z coordinate. Any condition detected by the Area Not Closed in Z will also be detected by the Unclosed Area inspection. When an area feature has different first and last coordinates, the distance between those coordinates is calculated and compared to the specified tolerance. This distance is measured in 3D for three dimensional features and in 2D for two dimensional features. When the measured distance is greater than the specified tolerance, a condition is reported.

Could be solved by using another GDAL driver or Arcpy to view geometry in python (outside of postgis). Needs a spike to test if other drivers or arcpy close the polygon like ogr has been doing (when importing to postgis). 
Also, why would a simple topological check need UTM?!
